No comment

Best Udon Place in the City. The texture was immaculate and I loved the quick service. The broth was deep and flavorful. I also loved the Age Dashi Tofu and was executed perfectly. I only tried hot udon and next time am excited to try cold. Only two drawbacks are that it is CASH ONLY and the restaurant was a bit cramped/small.
No comment

It was cash only but they never mentioned it to us, and there was no sign notifying it either. Food was not as good as their mcdougal location. The noodles were undercooked, fried tempura was soggy, and the broth was really salty. Service was fine, but it was an inconvenience having to walk 15 minutes to take out cash especially in the freezing cold.
No comment

Ordered the chicken tatsuta-age to start. The chicken was extremely juicy and fried well but I was not a big fan of the sauce, which seemed like a vinegar based, mild, chipotle mayo. The pieces were fairly large and a small was definately enough for 2. For mains, we ordered the spicy niku and curry with washuyu beef. We added a poached egg and shiitake mushroom to each, and also mochi to the curry udon. The noodles came in a massive bowl, and had a decent amount of toppings. I absolutely loved the spicy niku broth, which had a lot of flavor but didn't feel too heavy. My girlfriend liked the curry broth, though I felt it was a little watery. The short ribs were tender and the honeycomb tripe added a unique texture to the dish. Both eggs were perfectly poached. The shiitake was also delicious - it's marinated/preserved in some type of sweet soy sauce and has a very firm texture - but we were a bit surprised we only received one piece each. All in, I'd be happy to return and order the Spicy Niku again with the same add-ons.
No comment

I understand the "must seat complete parties" rule, but this little hole in the wall is so small there's virtually no difference set up wise between seating 1 or 2 persons. You can't even be seated 5 mins before your date arrives so you can nab a good seat and enjoy the food together. Very unromantic. Only going to the one on the West side now. Service is always better there too.
No comment
No comment
Fun udon spot, good broth and noodle selection. Admittedly was interested in trying their cold noodles that day but they were out unfortunately.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

NYC is famous for a lot of things and amongst the list is Ramen. So naturally there is a myriad of options for Ramen and Noodles in the city because everyone wants a piece of the pie but Raku is a diamond in the rough. It may not be as well known and high-fi as the other big ones like Ippudo and Momofuku but its homey, authentic and delicious. Personal favorites from my group of friends were the Tantan, Niku and Curry ramen. Reservations aren't terribly hard to come by and it s great for groups so next time you're in the mood for some ramen, check out Raku!

Okay, I'm not exactly sure what happened here, but the Spicy Niku Udon here did not blow my mind like it did at the Raku in Soho. Maybe I knew what to expect, or maybe I'm losing my taste buds (I should probably get covid tested) but this soup was only okay. The noodle texture and tripe were pretty good, and the pieces of beef were THICK so the chef really hooked me up with that one, but it didn't blow my mind the same way it did the first time. This venue was also much smaller and dimmer and not as delicately decorated, so if you have the chance please go to the other one for a better overall dining experience. This place was also cash only but they have this ATM machine in the back that you could use to withdraw cash. Though, I must say, the young and fun staff was definitely a plus, and they were really efficient despite nearly spilling the Niku on my friend when setting the bowl down on the table. It was all good though because we all had a good laugh from it and probably would have laughed harder if it actually spilled :D
No comment

My friend brought me here stating that she loves the udon they serve so I came to try it out. It for sure wasn't a disappointment. What stood out for me was their fried chicken with their amazing homemade sauce. Their niku udon was also pretty good.

Great food - small space - excellent service - cash only. All of the food is very fresh, the noodles are clearly made in house. You can add youre name to the waitlist before arriving, otherwise it will be a wait.

My friend recommended us here. He tried this place previously and the ramen was good. With that said, you can expect that there will be a line or you can join the wait list on yelp. We weren't thinking of that and had to wait for 45mins. It was also because the table that we were waiting for forgot to bring cash. Yes, this is a cash only place, but this didn't bother us at all. We order the edamame, bacon, kamaage and shrimp tempura hot udon. We had to agree the food is good. I like their noodle because it wasn't the regular white udon from the store. They imported their noodle from Japan. Aside from the wait and the food, they are very efficient too. They constantly collected our empty plates or bowls and check with us too. We will definitely come back when we visit NYC again.
No comment

Walked in on a weeknight around 6:30 PM and got stool seats against the wall, bit of a squeeze but not too bad. My boyfriend and I shared the deep fried eggplant, Niku udon, fried chicken and gyoza. Only thing I wasn't crazy about was the gyoza. Overall a solid spot with tasty fare.

Delicious! Definitely one of the better udon places in New York. The udon here tasted freshly made, the soup broth is delicious and there is a good amount of variety. I particularly liked the tripe I had, since it had a great amount of flavor and is more unusual to find in udon restaurants.
The udon in this place is the best I ever had ! I've had the Niku udon and I keep dreaming about  this soup every time I leave this place. The only thing is a bit pricey but it is totally worth it!
No comment
No comment
No comment
Udon options are great and affordable. The dons, not really. I usually had the fried fish cake hot udon with extra beef. The beef tripe udon, tofu appetizer, and eggplant appetizer all taste great.
No comment

Still waiting on my water after not being assigned a server and being ignored at a table for 30 minutes. They were definitely short-staffed and we are doing our best to be patient but really bad attitude of male hostess and every other employee stares at you, until they get close enough to help out and acknowledge your presence. At that point hey keep their head down and keep walking pretending like you aren't there.
Best udon I had in my life. The udon noodle tastes SO good. Highly recommended! Super petite place, so make sure to make a reseration!

Udon is very good for the warm weather. Love the atmosphere in the restaurant. I'll be right back for sure.

The food always comes out quickly and the staff is very friendly. Best of all, the food is AMAZING. I wake up craving it, I travel from Brooklyn just to get their Wagyu beef curry udon. Highly recommend!

Need to reserve in advance because the place is a little small, but the food is really cheap for the amount you get (huge portions) and they have great vegetarian options!

A truly delightful and intimate experience. I spent an afternoon in manhattan and decided to treat myself to a solitary, contemplative early dinner. Raku fit the bill exceptionally well. The workers were kind and attentive, and the food came out quickly. The ohitashi shamed my at-home wilted spinach, as it was much more flavorful and softer on the pallet than I'd previously experienced. The zaru cold udon perfectly struck the balance between savory and umami and was prefect for a warm, contemplative Saturday afternoon. They have a multitude of vegetarian/vegan options as well!

Definitely the best udon place in the city. The wait will be long on the weekend so plan accordingly. Get the short ribs udon or the gyunan udon (this one is with sliced shabu beef). Get the agedashi tofu for appetizers because it's the best I've had in the city. The fried chicken was just ok for me but I think it could be good for a group of people to enjoy some chicken and beers! They only serve bottled beers and sakes and no draft beers. Super small but great for udon. Highly recommend!!!!

This is near the university so there were a fair number of students there, surprising because it was rather expensive. I had the cold udon with wasabi. It's a tiny hole in the wall so that is a plus for the atmosphere, but you don't feel the coziness of a hole in the wall 'good' place to hang out in. It feels cavelike in a cold anonymous way. The neutrals don't give it a sophisticated air, more like a sad underground train station kiosk.  There was a rowdy group of guys next to us...too much sake,they were very loud, but the waitress didn't seem to know how to handle them, because in the confined space of the restaurant, they were clearly annoying other guests than just us.  One knocked over a drink, the other gesticulating so wildly he swatted my friend and nearly knocked dishes from the hands of the waitress passing him a few time. And all thru the meal they were loud and vulgar, guy nearest us tossed his jacket on hitting my friend in the head. I took a star off because the space is very small which means atmosphere counts ALOT, and boorish guests make or break the experience. The waitress or owner should be able to control the space, like any respectable local pub in Japan, they maintain control over the guests as well as the food. I think the udon would have been ok, but I could hardly taste it. Compared to my experience with a udon hole in the wall in Osaka, this is definitely not as tasty, classy or pleasant.  Given the neighborhood having soo much to choose from, I would not go back.

They have a great sake options here one of the best I've had. The udon noodles here are thick and delicious but I thought the short rib meat was too fatty and hard. Trips was great and broth was okay!Good noodles though but not sure if it was worth the $18

Perfect meal after a long day, their udon noodles are always so springy/bouncy and their karaage was delicious! They don't take reservations so it's a first come first serve basis, my friend and I didn't wait too long around 20-30 mins, we also got a bottle of their plum wine which was a good balance of sweet and a little bit sour. I like the set up of their dividers indoors, made the small space feel a bit more geared towards you.

Amazing food that is incomparable to any other udon spot I've tried in the city. The price is also unbeatable. I love the sansai udon and fried chicken appetizer.

Was visiting NY this weekend and added this place to my bookmark because I LOVE udon and i wanted to try it out! It was kind of hard to find the restaurant but we saw some pictures on yelp and that helped us find the front of the restaurant. It's literally a hole in the wall and there's only around 7 tables inside. We went right when they opened so it wasn't packed but slowly people started arriving as we ordered. Server was really friendly and the udon was AMAZING. I got the wakame udon, niku, and the katsu-don. I liked the wakame udon the best. It tasted really fresh and the noodles were chewy as well. The niku was a bit heavy for me but it was still really good. The Katsu-don was great! It comes with a pickled vegetable that goes well with the bowl.

At the end, they bring out a couple frozen grapes. The place is small but even if you have to wait a bit, it's worth it!

I was in the area and wanted to check this place out after hearing so many good reviews.  My friend and I both ordered the curry udon (chicken and beef).  It was very flavorful and rich.  I appreciated the greens and the homemade udon noodles.  They also provide a glass of ice water since the curry was a bit spicy.  Service was fast and attentive.  I think this is my go-to place for udon instead of Tsurutontan Udon in union square.  It's more affordable ($12-$20 for a bowl of udon) and the place reminded me of the old school udon places in Japan I've been to.  I'll definitely be back if I'm ever in the area.  FYI - its cash only.

Love love love this place. Best food I've had in NYC so far, hands down.  The broth was so good I almost slurped the whole bowl (and the bowl was huge, mind you). The food was so well seasoned so you don't feel thirsty afterward. I got the chirashi udon (chicken with mochi), which was perfect. Will definitely come back.

Absolutely heavenly bowl of Udon and nice variety of appetizers to choose from. Small  and cozy gem  in the East Village, usually a wait but the line goes by pretty quickly. I had this beef udon and the broth was delicious. Great for a date spot, dinner or lunch.

I've heard about raku for a long time and I always wondered "udon is good but how good can it be?" And then I finally tried it. I'm just thankful I don't live near the place because I would probably eat there everyday. The noodle is what really sets Raku apart from other udon places that I've tried. It's chewy - still soft, but has more depth to it when you chew. The broth / flavor is also great (I've tried the niku, duck breast, and jaja udon) - clean, all the ingredients compliment each other very well. I could go on and on about how amazing this place is but you won't really know until you go and check it out yourself.

As for starter, we got the chicken tatasu. It was so crispy outside and juicy outside. It's a must get when you come here if you like chicken. For the udon, i got the niku udon. The broth was delicious and the noodle was so bouncy. My bf got the ebiten udon. He really like the fried shrimp and eggplant. I would come back here for the udon since it's freshly made. Really disappointed that they don't serve the shrimp tempura add on and shrimp tempura udon for delivery. That's my favorite item and why they don't have it on a the delivery menu is such a big disappointment.

There is a difference between freshly made udon and the others.  The noodle has a snap unlike the mushiness of the packaged kind.  This little East Village noodle shop is understated with no shop sign except for a little wooden plaque on the outside with its name carved in Japanese.  Besides udon there are side dishes and donburi but the main attraction is the udon.  The gyunan or beef belly was tasty and not greasy. I want to order the fried chicken next time or try the katsudon.  We got in with no problem at 4:00 pm but the place only has about 20 seats so there's potential to have a wait.  Unlike ramen which tends to overdo the ingredients, the udon is cleaner and the broth is lighter.  It is cash only but there is an ATM inside if needed. If you're in the mood for soup noodles without the heaviness of ramen, you must try Raku.

I got the zaru with the minced pork, which was amazing. Though the best part of Raku had to be the toastiness of its interior. I'm still uncertain as to how it's heated, but upon entering from the wintery cold, a sauna-like heat, with what I thought was a hint of salt (though I could be hallucinating) washes over you. It smells woody and Earthy and is the perfect appetizer for a nice bold of hot (or in my case: cold) udon.
So good.  I loved it.  Service was good and udon was excellent.  It's pretty good size too.  Its a small yet busy place so reserve before you go. I'd come here again.

I'm not sure how I feel about this place honestly. I was excited to try this place due to the great reviews and I liked it but I didn't love it. I ordered the karage and pork gyoza to start. The karage was my favorite part of the meal but the pork gyoza was mediocre at best. My friends got the curry wagyu udon and I got the Niku udon since it was recommended and seemed very popular. The udon was very clean tasting and definitely what I would want if I was feeling under the weather. The udon was good; it was very silky and slipped right out of my chopsticks. Overall, it was good but didn't hit the spot like I had expected. My friends were thoroughly unimpressed by the curry udon. The wagyu beef was very dry and tasted kind of like hot pot beef and the broth was a little bit on the blander side and didn't have that curry kick they were looking for. Other than the food, my experience wasn't that greatest. The hostess was EXTREMELY rude to us. My friends got their first and put down their names before I had arrived. I mistakenly put down my name as well unknowingly and the hostess stormed out of the restaurant with the worst attitude asking us if we were the same group and then proceeded to scold us and tell us that she would now have to delete one of the reservations. It was a simple mistake and she could've told us nicely. When we entered, our server was nice so I don't want to say that the overall service was bad.  The place only accepts cash so if you do go, make sure to bring some cash.

Fabulous little cosy place, serving outstanding Udon dishes. The noodles are homemade and super fresh. The broths, especially the fish based, are fantastic. Service is good as well - friendly, quick and accommodating. I especially recommend the curry udon dish. As weather gets colder, this place will be the perfect culinary yummy shelter.

This place was literally a hidden gem! You could very easily walk by the white exterior with mackerel skin curtains that hide the entrance to this small and simply designed udon noodle heaven. We were told the wait was going to be an hour for two, but received a text that the table was ready in less than 45 min! I was not surprised that we had to wait. It says more abt the size of the restaurant than the popularity as it could probably only fit about 25 patrons. We split the fried chicken, which was deliciously fried. I've had better and made better spicy mayo sauce though. Good thing the chicken was tasty enough without the mayo. We both got the niku udon with the tripe and beef. I've never had such silky fresh udon noodles before! Definitely worth eating in as many different broths and sides as possible. The meat was also very juicy and tender! The broth was flavorful and not too salty! The place would've definitely gotten 5 stars if not for the wait and the noodle bowls being 17 dollars a bowl, not including tax.

Note to veggies: only one hot udon option (others made with fish sauce), so I went with cold yamakake udon but warmed myself up with warm saki. Delicious, subtle flavors.

The environment is pleasant. Staff is friendly and attentive. Food was amazing and plentiful! Perfect texture and consistency for the noodles. The Niku and Tantan noodles were delicious.

Went there on a Sunday afternoon with 2 friends. Had to wait around 35-40 minutes to get seated since the place itself is pretty small. We ordered the fried chicken (chickrn tatsuta-age) for app and Niku udon noodles, ebiten udon and  Gyunan Udon dish for entrees. The appetizer was ok, well fried chicken but I wouldn't compare it to Korean Fried Chicken. The udon however were phenomenal! Especially the niku udon. Rich broth with chewy delicious udon noodles! We felt like the gyunan udon was similar to the niku udon but with a weaker broth

Great ambience and fantastic food and service! The restaurant really reminds me of Japan in every way.

This small restaurant at the corner of 6th street and 1st Ave seats 25 people. Udon is specialty; and a few donburi. The simple, discolored wooden signage on white washed wall is easy to miss. Cash only. Their udon noodles are flatter & chewier than normal ones. Serving size is good. We started with chicken karaage. Curry with beef came in thick and hot soup. The Niku (short rib), Ebiten (shrimp tempura), Kitzune (bean curd) were nicely done with tasty broth. Both cold noodles we tried Ja Ja (spicy miso) and Yamakake (yam with small quail egg) were very good. Wait staff were curt and non cheerful which is quite difference from our experience all over Japan where we were greeted with welcoming smiles.

4 star for food but the service can be a bit grungy especially with the tiny dining room. Prepare to wait even with reservations. I wish the counter women smiled a bit more. Would be more welcoming!

Always a great experience at Raku. They have the best udon hands down in the manhattan area and very comparable to the udon I've had in Japan. The texture is chewy and bouncy. I've always ordered the cold udon with the dipping sauce and it does not disappoint. They only thing I wished was that it comes with a meat or veggie versus having to pay additional for the order.

This place is my new favorite restaurant. Service here was good and quick and the food is even better! I had the niku udon and my friend had the duck udon. The udon noodles are amazing and they taste handmade and very fresh. None of that processed udon that you get at other restaurants. The noodles were a bit thinner but very chewy and perfectly al dente. The short ribs and beef tripe in my noodle soup was so flavorful and just melt in your mouth. The soup was full of beef flavor but still very light. My friend also loved her duck udon but said the duck meat was a bit overcooked. I would definitely come back and would get the niku udon again.
Best udon I've had hands down! Including shin udon in Tokyo!! Noodles are really slippery and chewy and sooo good especially the zaru udon. The wait is annoying but the shop itself is super cute.

If you're reading this because you're not sure which Japanese udon house would be the best, you're in luck. I'll tell you, this is THE spot. The udon noodles are cooked to perfection, the dons are so full of flavor that you're beyond content with every bite. It's hard to impress a girl who's from Japan with Japanese food in the states. But Raku has definitely won me over. This might just be my new place to bring visitors from outside of New York. This is the type of authenticity you need!!!
Possibly the best udon noodles I've had in my life. The chewy bite, oh my. I love the theme of this tiny place. Abstract with focus on wood. Very reflective of my experience in Japan.

Tiny location that you'll probably miss unless you're looking for it. Be prepared to wait or walk around Japantown while you're waiting. The chicken tatsuta-age is a must when you come here. Trust me, you'll probably want your own order. It is crispy moist perfection in a bite. I would come here for the chicken tatsuta-age over the udon to be honest. Oyakodon was classic and well made. It gives you a feeling of home and comes with sides of pickled vegetables and soup. The curry udon packs a punch and is spicy so be prepared.

Best udon in town hands down. The restaurant has a warm and cozy ambiance. Niku udon is always my go to bowl of hot udon!

BEST noodle I ever tried in NY and DMV area! It's so chewy and tasty. It was really worth it to wait. I also ordered katsudon with niku udon. I personally liked katsudon better than udon ( beef broth was too salty for me but noodle was AMAZING.)

My wife wants to eat hot noodle soup all winter around NYC...Raku was one of our first stops and they made her belly happy...this is a place we'll hit more than once.

Raku is definitely worth a visit (be sure not to walk past! It's a very low-key entrance on a busy street). They have an extensive menu, although I was disappointed they were out of my first-choice meal. Still, what I ordered was very tasty and in a large portion. The service was also quick.

Sorry but I just don't get it. Got the Niku udon like everyone seems to be going on about... salty. Beef was fine but nothing to praise over. A little dry even maybe. I guess if you're into drinking the broth as well as enjoying the rest of the udon, save your money and find another place that's not as overpriced and with a long wait (for dinner time.. I walked straight in at lunch). I would also like to say I tried their vegetarian (one of the "cheaper" options, I forget which one) and it was also meh but now I know after second try, it's really not worth the hype.

Love this gem! My cousins and I came here on a perfectly cold December afternoon, and we left beyond satisfied and with full belly's. We started with the chicken tatsuta-age which was perfectly crispy and seasoned well, with a hint of spice. The Agedashi tofu was also great. I ordered the Ankake udon and I still have dreams about how delicious it was. The broth was  silky, savory, rich, and I could not get enough of it. The udon was thick, deliciously chewy and had just the right amount of bite. The space inside is pretty small, so if you have a large group you'll likely have to wait a while but it is so worth it!

This is possibly the best udon place I have ever had! I am rarely a beef fan but the beef brisket and beef short ribs with the broth is A* ! I highly suggest this place if you want a taste of flavorful soup
One of the best hand cut udon!! I've been there several times and their quality and the flavor are remaining the same.

Very authentic and tasty udon in a small/cozy location that's just quintessentially Japanese. Raku is unique in that the broths have so much depth and flavor, the noodles are the perfect texture (and almost taste hand made, though I don't actually know if they are), and the toppings are so unique and things you won't find in your average seamless Japanese place.

This restaurant is super tiny and we were lucky to get a table right away. Be aware that it is a cash-only restaurant though! I had the curry udon and the broth was super fragrant. This was the first time though that I really loved the noodles more than the soup it came with - and this should be expected here! I wish i could have taken the noodles home uncooked and cook it myself. Yum yum.

Food was good, wait staff friendly. I wish there were clearer signs on the menu and inside the restaurant that this place is CASH ONLY.   I did not see any signs. Then they try to make you use their own ATM machine that probably charges you fees. Will not be returning.

I'm an avid packaged udon eater (and do love that packaged stuff a lot) but I had absolutely no clue what I was missing with handmade udon. Just as restaurant ramen and Shin ramen are both great but in totally different leagues (tbh different foods sharing the same name), Raku's udons are of a different class. Grab a beef udon here on a cold night.

I am normally not an udon fan but this place has good udon. I got the niku udon plus some yasai added - very delicious. The place is extremely tiny though so always expect some waiting time. We also ordered the tofu appetizer which was OK.

My Japanese boyfriend said it was the best udon he's had in New York. Great ambiance, quaint, and minimalistic. The music was a bit odd / did not fit the environment as they would play songs from Star Wars. We ordered the fried chicken and Niku Udon. Both orders were phenomenal. The udon had flavorful broth, tender beef, yummy tripe and thick noodles. I highly recommend putting your name down on the Yelp waitlist and walking over at the suggested time rather than waiting an hour at the location since wait times can get long

I loved the food here! The udon was really good! There really is no shortage of great options. There are definitely some downsides to this location tho. For one, the restaurant can be kinda hard to find. There is no sign and the entrance is simply a door with a curtain. Second, the space is very small. You're pretty cramped against everyone. Make sure you go with someone that you're comfortable getting close to!

This review is due to the bad service upon walking in on a Sunday evening. Completely turned us away when their were no hostess to greet us so everyone waiting was lost outside. As we made our way inside, it was small and packed. The lady made us all wait outside and she had the most rude attitude. We asked her two questions and her reply turned us away. Just because you're restaurant is a "little busy" on Sunday night at 8pm..there was no need for an attitude for your customers. We wanted to try out the restaurant but we won't be coming back. Your hostesses and servers should be aware who walks in and out of that restaurant.

Raku is just that: a casual resi with relaxed prices and generous portions. The chicken tatsu-age ($8) is ~6 pieces of marinated fried chicken packed with flavor. The pork of the katsu don ($14) was firmer than expected, which I liked. The green strip lining the pork cutlet is a seasoning typically mixed with rice, called furikake. It's unconventional and pretty, but it ultimately makes an already savory dish more savory. The donburi comes with a plain dashi soup and a side of pickled vegetables. Solid food for $$ pricing.

Little Japan in NYC experience- I really like the ambience of this place! Even though this place is tiny ( probably why there's always a wait) it makes me feel like I'm in a cozy Japanese restaurant. The appetizer, chicken, was really good! And the main UDON...First of all, I am not a udon person but the fell in love with the cold udon! Honestly I could taste all the ingredients, very simple, but that simple and clean taste at the end got me fall in lovee with this place! Donburi was on point too ( the bowl was so cute) I am definitely going back to try out some more udon!

First time came to a Japanese udon place and found this is the little treasure inside the east village! Very tiny place but has a good ambiance. This is the best udon noodle I've had so far,chewy and little sweet. Definitely will be back soon.

No comment

This place sparked my love of udon. It's a small place with a cozy feel, perfect for mid-winter lunch. Both times I came here, I got the chikara, a chicken and mochi cake udon bowl. The portions are perfectly satisfying, the chicken extremely tender and the broth's packed with flavor, though a bit on the salty end. The noodles aren't the traditionally thick udon (not sure if there's an option to get them thick) but the dish works quite well with the noodles being thinner. I went and tried different udon places after this one, and Raku remains my favorite.
Just amazing, I'm normally prepared and ready to take on big portions of tasty food but today I was defeated by the  Chicken rice bowl and the Niku Udon!

Came here on a Sunday afternoon for lunch luckily it was not crowded. Niku udon for sure, their noodles were chewy. Fried chicken was juicy. Ladies who worked here served quickly. And the frozen grape came as complimentary dessert was indeed very icy!

I found this shop on yelp and spent twenty minutes looking for it! The shop is plain and looks closed, but don't be fooled! Walk right in! The food was authentic and delicious without being too expensive!

Blink and you might just miss it. The door to the restaurant is somewhat concealed as there's no clear sign that what lies within is masterful. I had the short rib udon- a dish creatively pieced that respects the intrinsic flavor of each component. The udon had a silky smooth texture and an al dente bite. The short ribs were literally melting in my mouth, a testament to the utmost care and respect of its cook. The broth was decadent and left a lingering taste of pure luxury. Each ingredient shone in the dish- a rarity that requires an understanding and execution of equipoise in the simple yet complex.
Be aware, it's cash only place!!! Their noodles are authentic. Loved the meatball/eggplant appetizer.

I came here for the first time with a friend to catch-up. The food was very good, their portion sizes are quite generous, I would definitely say it's accurate to the price you pay. Very small space, therefore it can easily become noisy (keep this in mind when choosing the time for your meal). Our waitress was attentive but didn't hover. Overall good experience!

Loved the minimalist look:  very boxy dining room and mono-color artwork.  I was surprised to find no wait for walk-in on a Thursday night.  The place was filled but we got lucky.  I ordered the Niku Udon with tripe and brisket.  The udon was my favorite part.  The broth was great.  Meat and tripe were standard.  The combo with udon is not often seen but I love it nonetheless.  My husband ordered the tan-tan noodle.  The tan-tan spice definitely has a kick!  He enjoyed the minced pork, peanut butter and spiciness.  The portion was more than enough for dinner.  We were both full without ordering appetizers.

Came here on a Tuesday night with my boyfriend and it was pretty packed, also because Raku is surprisingly small; but hey the best things come in small packages right? The hostess took down my name and number and informed me that it'll be around a half hour wait and that I will receive a text when the table is ready. The wait was less than half an hour and the texting system gave us freedom to walk around during the wait time. My boyfriend got their popular Niku Udon (Beef tripe), the broth was so flavorful and the beef was tender and melts in your mouth. I got the Ankake Udon with a side of tempura, the Ankake broth was this thick, egg broth with a few vegetables. The flavor was way lighter than the Niku, very simple and not much special. The Udon though was so chewy and soft and it seemed as if there was an endless amount in the bowl!! Overall, a little crammed but good experience!

This is as good as it gets. Even in Japan this is it. It's really that amazing. I was super pleased. Ordered the chicken app and the kitsune udon. Both are just really amazing. The hand made udon makes the world of difference and the broth is stunning good. If you've never been to Japan and wondered how good udon is over there, come here and you'll found out.

Best noodle bar in the east village. As authentic as you can get, and worth the wait. They don't take reservations, so call ahead to check the line or go, put your name down, and stroll about the east village until they tell you the table is ready!

Try using the Yelp app to add to wait list to avoid walking there and being greeted by a long wait time. This staff here work efficiently and they make it happen in the relatively small dining area. I had the ja ja cold noodles w/pork and also tried the fried chicken and the gyoza.  All of the food came out fast and the portions were good. I've had the udon at their other location and wanted to try the cold noodles today. The ja ja was good, they give you an egg on the side too.

Stopped in here on a rainy day with friends, it was a great start to our day and didnt let the rain bog us down. The atmosphere was cool and there was suprisingly a ton of options to choose from! we each got something different and we were all very satisfied.

It's really small so highly recommended that you get there around the time they open to minimize the wait. There really is no waiting area inside. I got the crab udon with thick egg broth, and when they say thick it is thick. But the broth is really flavorful once you hit the bottom of the bowl. Also liked the texture of the udon, my friend that was with me expected it to be a bit softer, but I like a little bite to my noodles. Also recommend the fried chicken appetizer, it is really crispy but very juicy at the same time.

Authentic AF! Food was delicious, ambiance and service were amazing! Can't wait to come back!

Amazing, amazing really clean tasting broth. Stumbled upon this little gem today and my friend and I were really glad we did. I had the Wagyu Beef Udon and it really hit the spot on this rainy day. The interior is really minimalistic in the perfect way. The noodles were handmade and had the perfect slightly chewy texture. The ambiance was relaxed even though the restaurant was busy. Really clean tasting food, came out full in a happy way! The portions are big but I finished the whole thing! Definitely would come back to try the other options!

Best udon I've had outside of Japan!  The noodles were just the right texture and the broth had amazing flavor (and not too salty like so many other places in the US that I've been to).  Raku has restored my love for udon!

A hidden gem! Niku - short rib that falls apart with tenderness and fatty honeycomb tripe. The broth nourishes me when I'm sick. I can usually get a meal and a half-2 meals out of a bowl of udon. It is a great place to come if you cannot hear or cannot speak loudly. They make people wait outside so the intimate, brightly lit setting is homey and cozy.

I never been to any Udon places in NYC. And then only places I know is Udon West lol! So my friend told me about this place and recommended foods that I need to try. So I ordered Oyako Don, Niku Don for entree; fried tofu, ohitashi, and Tuna for appetizer. I have to say all of the food were great and delicious. I really really like the Udon! The broth was not to salty, just perfect, the tripe and Beef were very tendon and soft. I love it. The staff were really nice and polite. They greeted us as soon we walked in. Willl I recommend this place to my place? Hell yeah, I will!!!

Finally made it after wanting to try this place for a year! We decided to plan an early dinner around 5:30 on Saturday and luckily we were seated right away without any wait. Thank god because the weather was freezing so it was a perfect night for hot broth udon but would have been a miserable night for a long wait. But shortly after we sat down, the line was growing so be ready for a wait if you go around normal dinner time. We started with couple  appetizers - bacon and chicken tatsu-age and both were great. But Udons were definitely the highlight! We ordered Niku and duck udon. The duck udon was really great but I would definitely try the Niku. On cold winter nights I will be definitely be thinking about the amazing udon noodles with the delicious broth!

Udon is probably the hidden food behind ramen but raku really makes it stand out. I tried a few things there like the fried chicken, mackerel sushi, beef udon and beef curry udon,agedashi tofu. I think the mackerel is a acquired taste but there's a little too much salt maybe for my taste. The rest were pretty much great experience. Only downside is probably a small restaurant so seating can be limited. Might not be able to bring a bigger group of friends. But mainly the food is spot on

The best part of their udon is the noodles! They are vey chewy and you can tell it is hand made! There will be a wait when you visit them during prime meal time and this place is cash only

The curry udon is dank as hell. I got the beef udon and it was still pretty good, but definitely get the curry udon if you go here! The crab seafood udon is in an egg drop soup but it's also really good.
This is my new favorite. Amazing broth and seems to be hand-made udon noodle. Flavors are very well balanced. Wish they have bigger space.

Horrible service but Food was good. it was my birthday, one of the servers with yellow highlights ruined my birthday. She acted like very rude. Super yummy and flavorful udon! Got the yamakake cold udon. Great for the summer heat.

Favourite udon place in NYC. We went to raku's second location and honestly preferred it there. It had more of a restaurant feel. We ordered the deep fried eggplant- which was too oily but very rich in flavor and the niku ramen. The broth was sooo flavorful and the udon wqs uniquely chewy

All I can say is WOW! My NEW favorite udon spot!  Simply delish! Small but quaint. Cash only. No exterior signage so pay close attention so you don't walk by it. Great service, great ambiance, great food! Perfect portions. Will def return

The food is exactly what I was looking for. This place had the best sushi I've ever had. It's a bit of a trip for me to get there, but I would totally go back just for their takoyaki. Not too expensive, either! And in a cute neighborhood. Totally recommend it.

An elegant and simple restaurant with wonderful udon. I came here with a group of four at 4:30 and was seated right away. Service was quick and efficient. I got the sansai udon and enjoyed it very much. The noodles were delicious, white, and chewy; the broth was authentic; and the mountain vegetables were exactly what I had been looking for. The restaurant exuded clean and simple Japanese aesthetic, completing the charm of my meal. Highly recommend, and I hope to be back next time I'm in NYC.

The noodles were perfect thickness and firmness. The broth was very interesting unlike any noodles I've had before, a bit on the salty side but I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The place is small so waitlist is long, but we got in without waiting too long, probably because people dropped out.

When the first time I got the best popular one(beef something) , honestly I was disappointed. The udon soup was salty and little sticky so personally not good.. however some menu like gatsu-dong and mushroom udon were really awesome! If you have low threshold of a salty taste, I would recommend you to get a mushroom udon.

Oh my gosh. What a Beautiful work, beautiful food. I don't think I've had better Udon in my life. We ordered 3 different kind of Udon and I couldn't believe all of them had different dashi. I don't think I can ever go back to Tsurutontan after visiting here. I was so so so impressed. One amazing thing is their of rice. A simple bowl of rice was so shiny, moist, fluffy and tasty. Amazing Japanese pride. Thank you. Beyond delicious.

We ordered Niku udon, Jia Jia don, chicken tatsuta, ankimo, spent $60 in total. We highly recommend the chicken tatsuta, the meat is really tender. Ankimo is the fish liver, I myself like the taste of liver, so I would recommend Ankimo also.

I've had Raku twice so far. This place makes me wonder, what Udon have I been eating my entire life. I had the Niku Udon on both of my visits. It was superb and delicious. The noodle is served with large beef chunks and honeycomb tripe. The broth is amazing. Portion size is huge! The bowl is so big you can probably take a bath in it. Note that it's cash only, and it doesn't take any reservations. Don't forget to get the Chicken Tatsutaage for appetizers. You won't regret. This is by far my favorite Udon place in the City.
I wish I could eat their Kitsune udon everyday. The noodles were so good & broth was delicious. Chewy noodles all day!

This place is pretty good. I usually go to ramen restaurants, but my friend brought me here last time and I was in love. I didn't know there are Udon restaurants around. Recommend for people to try out this place!

Words can't accurately express how much I liked this place. I've never had udon that was so perfectly cooked. I got the duck and scallion and the broth was so rich in flavor. Unfortunately, I thought the duck was pretty tough but the broth and amazing noodles made up for it. My husband got the niku (beef short rib and honeycomb tripe) which was also delicious. I really don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu here and I can't wait to come back!
Good portion if you're hungry and craving for carb. Will recommend you order this if you are there at first time;)

What a hidden gem on the lower east side!! Very authentic Japanese cuisine. Could tell owners were Japanese. A very simple menu, but there is at least an order or two for everyone. Wait staff is very friendly! Space is tight, but then again most good restaurants in Manhattan are fairly small. Been here 2 times, and don't know when it would be my last ;) definitely check it out, but don't spoil the low profile vibes of the restaurant!

A very cozy restaurant with incredibly generous portion sizes (I've never seen such a big bowl used for udon before). Had the chicken tatsuta-age ($7) and the chicken curry udon ($14). Chicken tatsuta-age was nice but a bit fatty on some parts, though it came with a nice dipping sauce. The udon had a good texture mild kick of spice to it but overall wasn't too memorable/unique in terms of taste; perhaps this is the simplicity many yelpers here seem to otherwise enjoy. I left full but also wondered if I should have ordered another udon instead.

Raku serves up some awesome Udon varieties. The bowls are huge and portions are consequently filling. The honeycomb tripe definitely makes the niku udon a winner, while the curry udon is also quite delicious. The appetizers are great too -- the karaage is crispy without bones, the monkfish liver has a nice sauce to it. Service, however, was insanely slow. We had to waive to the staff to get anything moving. Also, for comfort, pray that you'll not be placed at the side bars.
Outstanding service, great food, unique restaurant. Alcohol options were good, I had a hot sake and really enjoyed it. A must if you are in the area.

Several great appetizers, especially the thick cut bacon. Relatively good noodles with flavorful broths. Frozen grapes at the end a nice touch. Cramped and uncomfortable seating. Overall a good experience and I would go again to test it a second time, but was not blown away

Raku in East village has a very cozy homey vibe. Tables are closer together and more of an intimate environment. My guests and I were seated immediately and our food came just on time! Nothing complain and it's one of the best Udon places in east village!

Great ambiance and fast service. Marinated fried chicken app was amazing and the udon is elevated, with amazing noodles and broth. Still think about it from time to time. Definitely worth the wait!

This is by far the best udon place I've had in New York. This is not your typical udon spot- I believe the udon is homemade. The noodles are so soft and chewy. When I came I had the short rib and honey comb udon and my friend had the kani one. My broth was very flavorful and the meat was so tender. My only complaint is that the broth got a little too salty for me towards the end. My friends crabmeat udon was filled with chunks of crabmeat. The service was really good. Just a note, the restaurant is very small and hidden so it's really easy to miss. I would definitely recommend this place if you're going with one or two friend. Don't come with large parties!

The soups are amazing! the best one was the beef and tripe (Niku Udon). The broth was super flavorful and enough to order extra noodles to enjoy with it. The udon noodles taste homemade and add a great taste to the soups. The fried chicken appetizer was also good with not a lot of fat - the dip was slightly spicy for me but seemed like it was only a spicy mayo combination. The atmosphere is tight but cute. I would say that the only two downfalls are that the soup comes out unbearably hot and takes a long time to cool down, that I left with a seared mouth that took a day to recoup. Also, it is super expensive for udon noodle soup and small Japanese dishes that it is not a place I will come to often, so it wont replace my udon go to on st.marks. FYI - CASH ONLY!
No comment
No comment

Have been waiting to try this restaurant for a long time since I first heard all the great reviews. Even with all the hype, everything was ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. We had an assortment of appetizers and they all exceeded our expectations. Their dishes are very authentic and reminiscent of my recent trip to Japan. The udon noodles though were DEFINITELY the highlight. We had the Niku and the Gyunan and they were both super tasty. The noodles they use are unique and just the right amount of chewiness. Their broth is complex and savoury. Can't wait to come back again.

What an awesome restaurant! Only in New York City can you get udon this amazing until midnight! I went at around 10:30pm. The restaurant is really small, so if you go during prime dinner time, I bet you may have to wait. I got the fried chicken to start, some sapporo draft beer and the mushroom udon. Everything was so delicious. The noodles are some of the best noodles I've ever had, and the soup had the perfect udon broth. Not too salty. Udon places are rare, unlike ramen places. This place did it right. This is the first good (REALLY good) udon I've had in America!!

I don't even like udon but this place is something else. I got their most popular dish. It was the beef ribs with tripe. Must get. Service was good, restaurants kinda small so make sure you go their early or else you'll end up waiting.

It's a tiny room, cash only, you'll have to wait... but not as long as at Ippudo. Everything was delicious: burdock root, gyoza, udon, chicken karaage. Everyone dining inside was too cool for school, young, edgy, urban and Japanese. They must be on to something, these kids.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
Love the noodle and soup. It is great to have something warm and light when you are catching a cold. They provide takeout service as well. The place is small but very popular.

Omg. Been to very good noodle places in Taiwan, Japan, etc, but this place tops the list. The broth is so clear yet savory. The beef is so tender. The chicken is also so juicy. And the mochi in the chicken one is sooooo good. Omg. Came in at 10pm and waited for 20min for a table.

Fantastic combination of east village appeal (ie hidden gem feel) and exquisitely fresh, extremely understated Japanese noodles. For vegetarians, there are really only cold soup options (which didn't take the prize for taste). The other soups come in gorgeous pottery bowls, are huge servings and the noodles are as fresh as noodles get. They are cash only but have the cutest tiny ATM in the restaurant.
No comment
Love the agedashi tofu and curry udon :) make sure to add your name to the yelp waitlist before you arrive to avoid waiting too long if you plan on going during a busy time
No comment

This place is just amazing. We have had many good udon before but their udon is one of the best. Their handmade udon noodle is cooked to perfection and tastefully chewy. We got few apps to start and they were all great. I got Niku udon and it was so delicious that I wanted to get the broth to go lol. My boyfriend had Chikara udon and that was also amazing. What a gem in the east village! Best udon in da city!! I'll come back when I visit NYC again next time.
No comment

Living in East Village, I'm just grateful that Raku exists. Eating out in New York isn't cheap, but Raku perfectly marries the good food with an affordable price. The udon noodle itself is perfection, and the broth is absolutely delicious. My go-to are usually the Kitsune and the Ankake (I'm a sucker for the classics) and if you feel like splurging a little more, I'd recommend the chicken tatsuta-age, and the agadeshi tofu. Do remember this restaurant is cash only, so if you want to save the ATM fee, bring some cash with you.
Waited over an hour past the expected time. Very limited and flavorless options for vegetarians/vegans. Seated facing a blank wall in a tight corner and the draft kept us chilly throughout the meal.
Amazing udon and katsu don.  The the egg and pork in the katsu don was perfectly cooked.  The dashi soup complimented the katsu.

Nice vibe inside wth limited seating. Food was ok. The udon noodles were good but the broth was not as tasty as I expected. Dumplings were very good however. I did not like the fact that it's cash only.
No comment

I love the udon serving here. I ordered a cold broth udon with yam and an quail egg. The udon absorbed the flavor of the cold broth and the texture of it tasted just right. The yam is fresh and ground evenly.

Hearty & Tasty. Definitely would recommend to anyone that thinks they don't like udon. I completely different experience. Before coming to Raku, I would never go out of my way to order udon. Now, I would come back just to have this same dish (and others!!). Definitely a big portion if you tend to eat lighter. Noodles were bouncy and the gyoza was delicious.

Best Udon in town!! I will give the Niku udon 5 stars because it is simply delicious. Very small restaurant and almost missed it as well. Seating really limited but went at around 5:30 and it was not crowded. If you are down to splurge $18 on a bowl of deliciousness, I highly recommend!!!
Love the niku udon here! very tender short rib and honeycomb stripe~ not the typical round shaped udon you used to see in other place. very chewy and good taste. h

Pro tip- you can get on the waitlist via yelp if you're within a mile of Raku! Also, it's cash only!! On a Friday night waited about 50 mins for a table- Raku is an intimate restaurant featuring ~30 seats so I'd expect this is a normal wait time on weekends. They have a wide variety of both cold and hot udon dishes. I ordered the ankaki udon + added pork and a poached egg- I also enjoyed a glass of plum wine. I paid about $40 for my meal and was pleased. Only reason I'd give a 4 star vs. 5 is due to wait time and price point. I felt a little rushed when I was there but overall service was excellent. Would totally recommend this place and looking forward to coming back.
No comment

Nothing beats a bowl of freshly made, tender but also a bit chewy udon in delicious broth accompanied by marinated fried chicken on a rainy & cold day in new york. Get there early and do not take any detours even if you think you have ample time to spare - we left for the place at 10ish on a Sunday morning thinking we were super early, made a stop at Kmart, got there some 25mins past their open time and were given 25 minutes to wait, practically standing on our toes amongst six tables of slurpers in the tiny room that is Raku. If you like large chunks of beef with flanks, go for the renowned Niku udon, but be warned of the saltier broth. Know that whatever noodle bowl you get, there won't be a shortage of content, so go light on the additional orders.

Raku is a quaint little place for udon noodle. If you don't know where the place is, you might just walk by it. The decor is very basic. I had a udon noodle with tripe and short rib and my friend had a vegetable tempura udon. My udon dish was not very exciting, several pieces of beef and tripe in a broth. It was definitely not worth the amount of money i paid for it. The vegetable tempura udon was worst I felt in the amount of vegetable they gave. It was just some shredded green pepper, onion and something else. It was definitely not worth it. I also had the bacon, it was disappointing. It was more like smoked ham than bacon. The whole thing costed me about $50 after tips. I don't understand the ratings everyone gave them. I guess people were being more generous than giving them an accurate rating.
They have the best udon in NYC! Service is perfect, and the bacon appetizer is a must try!
One of the best noodle places I've been to in the city. This is a very small restaurant and is cash only. But the food is amazing!

Oh my gosh, this udon is on point. It's hand made noodles, do I need to say more. The Niku broth was absolutely delicious. Also had the fried chicken and age tofu. Both were super yummy. I'd def would go back, expect a line tho cause it's a small space.
is a cozy nook on the LES, with some brilliant udon dishes, especially the Niku (which feels like Raku's signature dish). Their fried chicken is very nice as well. Raku is worth its high wait times.

I really liked the aesthetics of this place! The service was great as well. I quite enjoyed my food, but the udon was different. It wasn't completely round and it was doughier rather than that sort of snappy chew that you expect. I didn't dislike it, but I came for udon and got something that seemed different. My soup was still very tasty, and I enjoyed the experience, but perhaps go elsewhere if you're seeking really fat, chewy udon.
No comment
So so good. When the food makes your soul feel better, you know it's good. The broth really settles the body on a chilly day!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
The noodles were ok. I prefer my udon noodles thick and soft. Their noodles tasted thinner and  al'dente. Their dashi soup is very nice. I had chicken mochi udon. Chicken was very tender.

Having gone to Japan two months ago, I've really been craving some good Udon. After scouring the internet looking and hoping for another euphoric bowl of Udon - I'm glad to have come across Raku. What makes or breaks a good bowl of noodles is the texture, in my opinion. Raku's Udon was slimy and not as chewy as I wanted, but it was still pretty dang good. My friend got the shrimp tempura udon - after claiming he wouldn't order anything since he was "full" - but upon walking in, he knew that he couldn't pass up this opportunity for some authentic Japanese Udon. I got the simple egg udon which was exactly what I wanted. The broth was a little saltier than I'd like and a little too simple for my taste, but the egg and the vegetables made it worth it. Also, it was a little chilly outside and nothing makes you feel better than a hot bowl of noodle soup on a chilly New York day. Pretty easy to find, we got there right at 11:30 on a Saturday and snagged the last table of 2. Other people after us got seats at the bar and the wait quickly became 30-40 minutes after we seated (we were super lucky!). Come hungry, leave satisfied. Good Udon, but still on the search for one that mimics Shin Udon in Shinjuku ;'( Message me any recommendations!
No comment

I enjoyed a nice, warm dinner on a cold night with a good friend.  The fried pork dumplings were a great way to start the meal.  I have to admit; I didn't love my duck udon.  But I don't think I didn't love it because it wasn't good, I just don't think I'm a big udon fan.  I prefer ramen.

Came here with my two friends. The place seems to be hidden. We walked right past it. There's no giant sign that say Raku. Instead, there's a small menu right outside. It is a small, cozy, and authentic looking Japanese place. The decor was nice. I ordered the curry beef udon. It was delicious. It was very flavorful with a mild spice to it. The broth was thick at first but once I started eating up all the noodles, the broth was much thinner. I usually like my soup broth to be thinner so I can slurp it. I would definitely come back and try the other udon noodles!

This place is solid! Their udon noodles are freshly made and chewy, definitely one of the best udon noodles I've ever had. I ordered their niku udon which is a beef broth based udon with beef briskets and honeycomb tripes, YUM YUM!!!

Cozy place reminiscent of what one could expect to find in Japan.  I had the Oyako Don and Gyoza. Both were delicious. Service is friendly.  My wife had Sansai Udon - comes with a huge mountain of veg tempura. She loved it as well. Must visit again.

I recommend this place if you're in the mood for a good bowl of udon. It's super small and quaint. The outside entrance is really cute and kind of takes you away. I got the niku udon which is pretty meaty but doesn't feel heavy.
No comment

Raku continues to be an unassuming and unpretentious jewel in NYC's noodle scene. A small, intimate space, Raku's simplicity works well and produces a serene environment. To me, the cold noodles are the real treat, but arrive early to get Japanese potato salad which quickly sells out. In all honesty, it's probably also the best hot noodles in NYC. Cash only, they have a cute ATM in a cabinet.
No comment
No comment
Best udon in the city! The noodles have the perfect bite to them. I'm all about the Niku Udon! The beef and honeycomb tripe! Can't wait to go back! Huge portions as well!
No comment
No comment

The best udon spot in the city!! Came here with my boyfriend around 12pm and we waited for 10 minutes for seats. The interior is very simplistic and has a very cozy feel to it. We ordered the small chicken tatsuta-age - it was very delicious with the spicy mayo sauce. I got the Niku hot udon (short rib and tripe) - everything about it was perfect. The broth was very rich and delicious and the beef was very tender. There was a good amount of beef and tripe which I was very happy about. Definitely would recommend coming here!!

Simple and good food. Excellent place if you are looking for good Udon and some small plates to nosh on with the delicious chewy noodles. My favorite so far is the seaweed udon and the plain udon with dipping sauce. The chicken udon had a good broth but the mochi was not exactly what I expected. The shrimp tempura udon was good but the broth needed a little extra kick to it which was easily fixed with the spicy sesame seasoning that they had on the table. Looking forward to the next visit where I plan to try the gyoza which seem to be a pretty popular appetizer.
No comment
No comment

Amazing little treasure find with one of the best udon noodles ever! Small and quaint with a minimalistic feel to it, and great for small and intimate gatherings. Definitely worth the wait, staff is always soo nice and helpful.

Great food, great vibe, great spot! A small dinner place to meet up with one to two friends! The noodles are amazing and I love the frozen grapes they give with the check! Definitely check it out, it is now one of my favorite spots in the city to eat at!
No comment

The UDON noodles were amazing. I got the red crab udon with seaweed. The service was fast. The broth was light and clean tasting. The poached egg was cooked perfectly. If you want great Udon come here. Prices are very reasonable.
No comment

Saw the amazing reviews, so I decided to give this place a try. Maybe it was just the bowl I got or the day I went, but I was less than impressed. Certainly a huge portion of udon (I split it with one other person), but it wasn't outstanding in any way. Hits the spot if you're looking for udon in the East Village, though.
No comment

Stopped by on a Tuesday afternoon and it was relatively empty. Simple and clean exterior and interior. The space is small but more spacious than I expected. Polite and courteous staff. I ordered the ankake udon at around $10 and it was quite unlike other udon bowls I've tried. The bowl contained noodles, spinach, scallions, egg and ginger, apart from the broth. The broth was clear but really thick - gel-like. The noodles were chewy. I found the ginger taste a little bit too strong for my liking. Personally, I wasn't too crazy over this dish. Would recommend to those who seek unique twists on udon and/or appreciate a good dining environment.

This place is quite excellent. Well most other places have an option of about 3 to 5 Udon choices, this place had at least a dozen. My husband ordered gyunan udon and I ordered an unatama donburi. My dish had so much flavor and came wih some yummy soup and pickles on the side. We also got a bottle of cold sake which was such a great addition to the warm evening. This place is incredibly small so be prepared to wait it out!
The surrounding and the whole space is so chill and comforting. I like how Japanese restaurants usually keep their details perfect. Definitely going next time.

The niku udon is amazing, the broth is a bit on the sweeter side but I enjoyed it. The store is quite small so get there before it gets packed! The udon noodles are super soft and chewy. I would definitely come back for the niku udon!
No comment
No comment

I love the udon here. Every time, I have a great experience. It's just a small little shop you can easily walk by and miss. On the other hand, every bowl of udon I've had here has had all the perfect flavors and didn't lack anything. It's a must if you like udon noodles.
No comment
Good food, but shitty attitude. Very tinny space, they should really consider how to treat costumer well.

Hands down one of the best Udon bowls I've had in recent memories. I had the Chikara udon with added poached egg and shrimp tempura, which were fantastic. The appetizer that we shared, the chiken Tatsuta-age was also superb. Expect a 15-30 minutes wait, but you can leave your number and come back when they text you.
No comment
Best udon ever! I got the one with mochi in it. Never had mochi in a savory dish. It was yum. Seriously, don't miss this restaurant. Everything was executed to perfection. Cash only.
This place is a piece of Japan in NY. Amazing udon! The service is also impeccable. Highly recommend

I came to Raku on a Monday night when I was really craving Japanese noodles. This place is really amazing and authentic the soup base is very umami and the noodles were the perfect consistency. I got the nameko udon and all the mushrooms were so fresh and cooked perfectly. Even though I was full half way through, I kept eating because I knew it wouldn't taste the same if I took home a to-go box . So definitely my go to noodle shop in the east village

I've been to raku atleast six times and each time I go it never dissapoints. The quality of the udon noodles is amazing and I also love the agedashi tofu and the edamame. The only issue is that it gets packed very quickly and they don't take credit cards. Would 100% recommend to anyone who is looking for some warm udon noodles on a cold wintery New York day!
Delish food and great service!! We got lucky and didn't even have to wait in line for seating. Get the niku hot udon and jaja cold udon.
Good fried chicken and fried tofu app.  Udons are better than average.  Had the egg based one with crab and beef one.  All good

Best udon I've had in the city! It's an extremely small place but once you go inside you feel as though you've been transported into a real noodle shop in Japan. It has a real simple and Zen feel to it. Anyway, I ordered the Ebiten Udon (Shrimp Tempura) and when it came out I was pleasantly surprised to see that there were two lightly fried pieces of shrimp and a slice of eggplant tempura sitting on a plate above a deep bowl of steaming hot udon. Usually the shrimp is already in the broth and then it gets all soggy by the time it reaches your table, so I enjoyed the fact they separated them and the way it was presented overall. Anyway, the broth itself is really light yet deep in flavor and honestly the favorite part for me was the chewy noodles. The noodles were thick but look and tasted freshly made and hand cut. It was just the perfect texture and comes with a nice amount of spinach. I thought that it wouldn't be filling (I have a big appetite), but that bowl is deeper than you might imagine and there was a good hefty amount of noodles. You basically won't leave there stinkin' full, but you won't be hungry either. Anyway, I would definitely come back to try more! The Ebiten I ordered was $14, and most of the noodles will range from $12-$18. Oh, and it's CASH ONLY.
food is fantastic environment is fantastic but the services is just so so. If service if not a big deal to you then Raku is a good place for enjoying  meal.

Everything here is amazing! The noodles are cooked to perfection with the perfect chewiness udon should have. The soup is clear and flavourful, it's hard to not drink it all. I've tried almost half the udon choices here and haven't been disappointed yet! This is a must try and a must come-back-to restaurant!

Warm hot soup with Japanese thick cut udon noodles. We got the dumplings for starters and was definitely not disappointed. This place is a well curated small intimate space, carefully designed with well crafted wooden small  tables and wooden side table bar seating. I loved my egg drop soup with noodles. Food is absolutely delicious with warm service. Perfect for any chilly winter night in NYC!

The place was soooooooo tiny... Nonetheless, the foods were amazing. It was huge and delicious. The noodles tasted like home-made udon with the texture of ramen and udon. Soup was so tasty. RECOMMENDED!

The food here is outstanding. I had the ebiten udon and added the fried bean curd - so so good. Wish I would have seen the other reviews first and I would have tried the karage. I just came back from Tokyo a few weeks ago and this is as good or better than any udon I had there. You can reserve a place in line on Yelp and I recommend doing so. Also warning: cash only!
No comment

This is one of my favorite noodle places! It's very subtle and minimalistic, which I love and the food is always so good! If you come here, you definitely have to order udon, and there are several types to choose from, plus toppings if you want a little something extra. The noodles are fresh and chewy and always served piping hot (unless you order cold udon). The workers are polite and helpful and always fulfill a request quickly. The only downsides to this restaurant are that: 1) it's a cash only establishment, so if you want to eat here, be sure to bring $20-30 per person and 2) it's very small and they don't take reservations as far as I know so you're unlikely to be seated immediately if you have a medium to large sized group. Other than that, this restaurant is one you should definitely go to!
To go spot for udon. This place is really small, it can get really busy during dinner time. But overall, this place is good and its CASH ONLY.

This is my third time at Raku and i have to say it hasn't let me down at all. I had the katsu-don, the duck breast the short rib udon and man... the quality of the soup and the meat are phenomenal! The space inside is rather small, but the ambiance is also another great thing about this place. Definitely will be my go-to noodle spot for a good while
First time trying the handmade udon, that was really good. The soup wasn't strong and salty like others. But CASH ONLY really took some points off!!!
No comment

Amazing. Best soups in nyc! I love coming here. It's such a small and cute Restarant. Yes the wait is over thirty minutes usually every time I come. But I can't not go here. I love the environment and the food here. This place will always be my go to udon soup place.
No comment
This is the best niku udon I have ever had! The beef was delicious! And the fried chicken was also wonderful!!!!! The tofu looks good, but not my style...

My favorite udon in the city by far. I introduce only the people I trust to this tiny sanctuary with handmade udon and some of the best broth I've ever tried. The niku udon is reminiscent of Taiwanese beef noodle soup and pho and so, so wonderful.
No comment

This place is like a hidden gem! Makes you feel like your in Japan. The food is good overall but some broths can be a bit salty. The service is good and the frozen grapes for dessert was awesome! Definitely will be revisiting.

Love this udon place! I always get the edamame (salted perfectly) & niku udon. The noodles are handpulled, soup and ingredients are fresh and authentic. **It's cash only and sometimes there is a wait (although it's totally worth the wait). Highly recommend!

I remember coming here around a year ago during the height of December when the East Coast was at its coldest. My brother and his girlfriend decided to take me here for a fun time. The Chikara Udon is incredibly delicious and the homemade udon really do make a difference. The texture is unbeatable and they absorb the soup perfectly. The mochi was also a perfect delight of chewiness and stretchiness; I would recognize anything else. Please go here!
Small family run udon shop. High quality broth and noodles. Great on a cool, rainy day.
No comment

Came here spontaneously with my family last night. Since it started getting cold, we were all craving something hot and soupy. This place is pretty small but that's just how it is in East Village. Luckily, there were available seats when we came in but a few minutes later - the place was packed. We each ordered different udon. My mom had the duck and my sister ordered the Niku (beef with tripe). I got the Gyunan udon that came with wagyu beef and negi. What really impressed me was the noodles themselves, it's not the typical factory made udon but actually looks like it's handmade! The broth is just right in terms of flavor; however I wish it was a little more dense as I personally like thicker broths. If you're ever up for some udon, I would definitely recommend giving this place a try!
This place has the best affordable udon I've had! The service was great and the store's aesthetic is cozy.

Absolutely love the food here but at the end of my meal, the waiter asked if we'd like ice cream so of course we said yes. When we got the check, we had been charged for the ice cream. Would be nice if the waiter could mention that it's an additional charge and not just something nice they include with the meal haha. It was a surprising add on.
First meal in East Village. A really small place but really amazing food!
I don't like soup but this is somehow the best soup I've ever had. Everything has a nice savory taste to it. The fried chicken is great too.
Noodles were awesome, the atmosphere was cozy and the servers were friendly. This place is cash only though!

I prefer soba, but Raku was pretty spot on with the udon. Raku's udon looks and tastes different than most udon places and it didn't feel like it was very heavy filling. I had the nameko udon adding mochi - very large portion and delicious. We also ordered agedashi tofu, which I would say was one of the best I've had in a very long time. Raku is very small, we got here at 6:00 on a Thursday summer night and had no problem getting a table. I will assume it must get very busy later. Cash only!!

Came here the other day for dinner and got the niku udon (short rib and tripe). It was sooo delicious. The noodles don't taste too doughy and the broth is very good. Perfect soup for a chilly night. I'll def be coming back again!

Solid udon, but not as amazing as all these reviews are making it out to be. The burdock root appetizer was quite good but a bit sweet, and the broth for both our udons was a bit too salty. I might try it again for the Niku udon but the sansai udon was not amazing.
No comment
The best udon noodles! The texture of the noodles was fantastic. I can't really explain it. Each bowl that we had was a delicious broth with different accompaniments. Also the seaweed app was great
No comment

I'm originally from Tokyo but sadly a lot of Japanese food doesn't live up to my standards here in New York because it doesn't taste right or it's too expensive. Raku is not the case. It's reasonably priced and very delicious. I went here with some of my friends from Japan and we had a great time. I believe I had the Jaja-udon, which is a cool combo of two of my favourite noodle dishes! I tell everyone I know this is the best udon spot in New York. And don't forget to mention, the interior decor is so cute too! And love that it's very small and doesn't seat many--so OG Nihon style
No comment

Waited for 40min to get a seat for two, because this is a small place. We ordered shrimp udon, swordfish liver and fried chicken. I like the texture of udon, very chewy. Chicken is better to eat with lemon juice only, sauce is too rich

Possibly the best udon I've ever had, The noodles are thick and yummy and the broth is rich. Super cute place, entrance is lowkey, made me miss Japan. Appetizers are wonderful I recommend chicken karage and the small fried fish. Cash only but they have an ATM in a cabinet by the kitchen.
No comment
Excellent. Clean, very simplistic yet very deep flavors. Great udon. Amazing decor, it really does look like that on the outside. Great service, very attentive. Great dashi.
No comment

Great noodles, BUT the service is the rudest I have experienced in a long time. First waitress tries to snatch my soba from me while still in the middle of slurping up noodles from a half full bowl. Can you please not? Upon finally finishing dinner, literally one 1 minute after we payed the check, second waitress comes up and asks us to leave because there is "a line out side". I tell them they are being rude. Response: Thank you so much for understanding! I DON'T understand. Please Raku, look at this line: "If this is supposed to be a come and go fast-food joint, please advertise so and adjust your prices. And please kick out your rude personnel". Never going here again. Zero Stars
Never really liked udon until I've tried this place. Absolutely delicious with fresh noodles, sake and more
No comment
Holy crap is this place good! Just go there and eat it. No further words needed.
Liked it a lot! Had unagi don instead of udon. Will definitely come and try udon another time

First of all, the restaurant is super easy to miss as there is no large sign. In a way, that makes it very seemingly secretive and only those looking for it will find it. Everything inside is very neatly organized, albeit a bit cozy. The lighting is warm and it complements the wooden tables well. The bathroom is even pretty cool as it has a sliding door and is well kept. As per other yelp reviews,  I tried the Niku Udon option and I definitely was not disappointed. Coming in a large black bowl, the soup fills it about 3/5 of the way. The broth has a very pleasant, savory smell that is very enticing. The udon noodles are chewy in a good way and not too soft at all. It absorbed the flavoring of the broth very well too although I would say the broth by itself is a tad too salty. The beef is still mildly red on inside and it tears easily apart with each bite. The beef tripe is very tender as well. Overall, it was a enjoyable environment and the food was quite excellent. It is a bit more expensive though but the experience is definitely worth it.

Came here for an early Saturday lunch. A very cozy kind of atmosphere. Ordered a two tempura udon which came with a large bowl of udon, spinach, and scallions as well as two shrimp tempura and eggplant. 10/10. Will definitely be coming back again.
No comment

My go to spot for udon. I love the nameko udon but chikara and niku are also great- I find the broth for niku a bit sweet. The pressed mackerel side was also very good. I really want to try the cold udon but can't resist the hot ones
Udon here is made in house and absolutely delicious. Agadachi was one of the best I have had! Very small restaurant with intimate seating. Worth it!

This small shop has a really authentic feel. The prices for the appetizers are super reasonable, would highly recommend the fried chicken and the deep fried tofu dishes. I'm a huge fan of udon so I was really excited to try their hot noodle dishes. They were very generous portions but nothing special. I had the curry beef udon so it might just be a bad pick (was expecting a curry consistency but instead it was very soupy), would be happy to come back and try other flavors to see if they are better!
No comment

If you're in nyc and have tried raku yet have you been to nyc?! Their hospitality and food and everything about the restaurant makes you want to go back! Plus the price is super reasonable! And did you know their udon is handmade!!!??

Small space with minimal distractions, Raku offers genuine cuisine with exceptional delicacy. Seats rotate quite efficiently to house as many craving customers as possible. Easily an East Village regular dinner spot for those in the know.
No comment

Yes, I liked the food. They had plenty of space and not a lot of people were eating anyways, but they wouldn't let me and my friend sit in the seating area but the balcony. They said because it's gonna get "busier", but by the time we left it didn't get any busier, but less people. So they should really learn how to give the best service for it is service in the end, not the taste of food that will bring back their customers. I ain't going back after how they treated us.

Their food doesn't look attractive on the photo and I was hesitate to go. But I'm glad that I trust yelp review and tried this place! Food was so yummy and udon was prefect! They probably hand made the udon, so it's very different and more delicious with the traditional udon you could buy from Asian supermarket. We also tried the fried chicken and fish liver.
