Food was fresh and the flavors were incredible. We were celebrating our anniversary and my cousin's upcoming nuptials. The service was impeccable. If you're looking for something special make a reservation here.
We were in the city and decided to have lunch here. We were seated right away.  We ordered the chicken and fish sandwiches. Portions were large. Food was very tasty. Service was great too.

Had such a great meal with some friends! It's a little chilly if you're seated in the outside portion but we were wearing our jackets and there were heaters. The food was im goodness sooooo good! Everything we ordered was so fresh and so delicious. The waiter was so helpful and even gave us tips on what to order, which worked out really well. We had such a blast besides the food and drinks being amazing. Some of the dishes that I highly recommend are: Cacio e Pepe Rice Cakes, Impossible Pork Rice Cakes, American Country Ham, Smoked Sweet & Sour Ribs, Sizzling Bavette Steak, and Whole Roasted Fish. They were all so drool worthy, really go there. I only got one picture because well it was all too good to take pictures of.

Food is great. Service is ok. Maybe because it was Sunday evening. I recommend Rib eye steak.

I was very disappointed. I took my girlfriend there for Valentine's Day and the prefix menu they had was a joke. And misleading. Food was under seasoned took a while for the food to come out.( wasn't even that busy)  cocktails were wack. And everything super over priced. 0 out of 10 do not recommend. David Chang needs to do something about that spot. It's wack.

Everything from the drinks to the appetizer was great. The raw food and chicken wings with the ribs were good. The entree of the steak, pork belly I did not like then seasoning of them was a little off. The scallops had a weird after taste. Was not as fresh as I would like. The raw salmon was really good. The raw beef a little bit too salty. The cheesecake dessert was not bad. But the shaved ice is pretty plain. Mix feeling about here. But would come back and try some other things also.

The food is excellent but our server is really bad and had bad attitude.  We ordered one set of pork bun and country ham he brought two sets of pork buns.... He never checked how we were doing during our meal and rushed us with check. It is a shame that such a good restaurant is lacking decent service
Great experience!  Delicious dinner, yummy drinks, and amazing staff. Went with a party of 8 and had the Ssam dinner. Amazing!

Overhyped. Way too salty. If someone made a high end version of what Panda Express is to Chinese food, Ssam bar would be that.
No comment

Been to every David Chang's places including MOMOFUKU Ko l, however this is the worst of his poor establishments. Ambiance was awkward. Serving staffs were so out all over the place. Menu itself is obnoxiously off balanced. Ssam Set ($105 per person) was terrible. Just couldn't wait to get out of there. Heavily salted and impossible to identify unpleasantly stimulating spices in all the dishes. Oysters were not fresh so we left 4 pieces out of 6 untouched. Striped Bass Tartare was basically cooked by hot weather temperature that tasted like wood. Prawns were uncooked. Short ribs, pork shoulder, pork belly were all over seasoned and the servers who grilled the meats for our table didn't even ask how we wanted our meats to be cooked. Drink menu was not making sense at all. Canned Korean rice wine and canned Korean flavored hard seltzer...? What a conspiracy. Hard to get servers' attention although they have tons of people on the floor. Please stop using Korean culinary terms in your menu and making your staffs to say them incorrectly. It's an insult to Korean heritage. My Thursday dinner got wasted down the drain.
No comment
Food and service were solid. The new waterfront location is beautiful, spacious and upscale - however it's missing the east side feel of the previous location...

Worst restaurant - do not go. Ssam bar moved to a commercial building and the tasteless food reflects the loss of culture. It's known for the rice cakes and it is NOT a rice cake - it was uncooked pieces of dough that tasted like nothing. Only reason I can give 1 star is because the drinks had enough alcohol to slightly distract me.

Service right on music great . It felt more like a restaurant that caters to a tourist crowd but after reading other reviews will give it one more shot since we only had the popcorn shrimp and the scallops.Shrimp was terrible PF Chang like except for the lettuce leaves. Scallops fresh with a lot of heat tasty but wouldn't order it again. Wine was good. Bit trendy with the dishes but didn't sample enough to give an overall assessment .
Minus the host ruining our surprise party by letting the birthday girl know "the rest of your party is upstairs"  the food was phenomenal and the drinks were strong.

The service was good, the food was not.  Everything was so bland, not much flavor.  I rather go to Ktown and have a full on Korean bbq meal over this any day.  I was exciting about the strawberry cheese shave ice, it was not bad but nothing wow about it either.   The salad was a salad, the popcorn shrimp was so boring, the pork belly was not flavorful at all.  I was very disappointed.

The bar is at Pier 17 with a nice view of the old vessel and Fidi. The short rib is really food, and the popcorn shrimp with Lettuce wrap is amazing! Cocktail is flavorful. A bit pricy for bar food though

Make sure you sit at a table and request a window seat. (If you don't, doesn't matter!) I got the prefix menu to get all of the experience. The food was great, atmosphere and service was top notch. Drinks were exotic, and tasted bomb. I would recommend for a date night or special occasion. The vibe was everything, will be returning!

The meal we had was good, it's just that we made a reservation about a month ago and all they had open was the "heated" patio. They stuck us in the corner where there were no heaters. The entire time there were open seats with heaters. Also when I went to the bathroom half the indoor tables were empty! And as of this was not enough, we got a blood orange "cheesecake" for dessert that was basically a runny yogurt parfait. If you've had Noosa or similar Greek yogurts, you've had this, only you saved a lot of money.

Momofuku Ssam is garbage compared to the noodle bar -- which imo. is 100x better. Ssam's quality is comparable to PF chang's. The fish was not fresh, the flavors fell flat, and nothing stood out. The view and staff are nice though.

Totally in love with the steak! Amazing customer service! Beautiful location by the water! Highly recommend!

Beautiful location right by the water! The pork belly & the wings were amazing. I am glad they have the Korean rice beer, Maekgolli. I have nothing but the best to say about all of David Chang's restaurants.
Incredible food! We got the margarita, the ribs, shrimp, cacio e pepe rice cakes, and the fish. All of it was incredible!!

Came here to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday last night. We didn't have a reservation (Thursday) so they put us on the wait list. We waited for an hour- nothing. Turns out that they had written the number down wrong and given the table to someone else. The manager was super apologetic and sat us almost immediately after that- literally as soon as another couple left and the table was cleared. We had the ribs, the American ham & baguette, white kimchi, and the steak. Let me tell you the sweet & sour ribs were the star of the show. Melt in your mouth juicy and seasoned to perfection. I would get a double order as my meal next time lol. Our server was super knowledgeable and attentive as well. Finally, I had to try the PB&J cocktail. I was skeptical but it really tasted like PB&J! It was actually so good. Highly recommend this restaurant even after the little fiasco with seating and be sure to book a reservation- half of that was our fault

Have to admit that I came with very high expectations, having been a long-time listener + viewer of Chang and fan of Chef Eunjo Park. To begin with, the Freisling was fantastic - ice cold till the very end with a delightful lychee flavor. The Hanami highball on the other hand was good but much more subtle than I expected. We had the popcorn shrimp to start and it was very good - a shrimp version of Korean sweet and sour fried chicken, with lettuce wraps and pickled daikon to balance out the grease. Delicious and fun to eat.  For the second course, we had raw scallops. It was a bit of a letdown to find out that they changed the kimbap dishes I've been eyeing to just crudo... Of course, it was a mistake on my part to make the assumption but really hope they keep carrying the kimbap :') And if they do I'll definitely come back for that. Finally, the steak ssam was fantastic - sizzling hot, perfectly cooked, with plenty of veggies and lettuce wraps to eat with.

No comment

What an amazing experience! The ambiance was great. It was a bit windy when we arrived. They lowered the windows/doors to make it more enjoyable. Our waitress, Clara, was very friendly and informative. Any questions we had were answered with confidence. The food was amazing! If you live in the area; GO. Ask for Clara.

Long time fan and patron of Momofuku restaurants including Noodle Bar, Ssam Bar, Booker and Dax, Nishi and Ko (my 40th birthday, a breathtakingly beautiful and moving experience). Painful and bizarre experience this evening in the Seaport. Arrived early to our dinner reservation at the bar. Waited a while for someone to offer us a drink but eventually bartender did so, and we ordered, happy and excited to eat at a restaurant we've missed in the pandemic, and had never eaten at since its move from the EV. Had the wine list and menus in front of us as we began to cheers our first cocktail and look at the menus. A person--server, manager?--came around to our bar seats in a nearly empty restaurant (there was only one other person there), reached over me and plucked away the wine list. I said in a friendly way: "I was planning on looking at the wine list for dinner." The person looked at me with deadlights, coldly saying: "Should I bring it back or were you planning on holding it for the duration?" with an edge. I looked around in confusion. "Do you need it right now?" Again, deadlights. As if I were holding open the train doors during rush hour preventing the world from moving. She said fine, keep it and brusquely left. Her attitude was the opposite of hospitable. It was provocative, and scornful and ad hominem. It's hard to convey the strangeness and the low grade contempt/rage of the person talking to us in this review. Who cares about the wine list? Not me! Certainly was happy to relinquish it if someone else needed it! But there was no one there in the restaurant besides us and this person's attitude was nothing but disagreeable bordering on hateful. My partner and I looked at each other in bewilderment. We debated what to do and agreed we had no desire to stay for a meal after such a strange and odious interaction. I paid the check for two cocktails and we left, abandoning a dinner we had been looking forward to for a week. I explained to the hostess the reason we were leaving on the way out. She seemed to intuit why we were leaving but didn't apologize, only said she hoped we found a place to eat that we liked, as if we were hard to please, entitled guests. Hard to imagine ever wanting to go back.

OMG, Momofuku Ssam Bar was definitely impressive. The atmosphere and staff are phenomenal. Every single thing that we ordered was incredibly fresh and delicious. The crew was really welcoming and service is perfect. Momofuku Ssam Bar...Check it out I say.
Saam Bar is one of NYC's great restaurants and I'm so excited for its new life in South Street Seaport.
Very disappointing experience at this restaurant. I would say just don't here so many restaurants in NYC don't waste your time going to this one unless you want to leave disappointe.
Popcorn shrimp was fantastic, a bit expensive but that's a given for the area. Great service and clean.

The relocated version of ssam bar is a shadow of its old self. It used to be one of the most creative restaurants in the city. It's all 'just okay' and doesn't do justice to the Momofuku brand. The mall-like environment in the new location also doesn't help.

Chef Jo is back!! Kawi was one of my fave spots in NYC but the location was dark and far. Well now it couldn't be brighter and closer to us in Brooklyn. Relaxed but attentive service. Lacking the pretense of other restaurants of this caliber but still you can tell the team was well trained. The salmon kimbap is a dream - especially as a NY Jew who loves a good bagel and lox. The sausage rice cake was one of the best dishes I've had in a very very long time. For the non-pork eaters, well and even if you are, the cacio is also crazy good. Shaved truffles on top?  Yes pls. And the namesake ssams- pork belly is to die for. Omg the ribs and the wings too!!  Can't wait to go back when it gets warmer and the glass garage door things are wide open. OHHH and the cocktails are awesome!!  Lightseed Champion is a star even tho I don't like rye. And the spicy Korean margarita is delish. And the wine list is stellar. Ok. Rant over. I love it. And I can't wait to come back.

I was a loyal customer at the now closed East Village Saam Bar.  I ate there at least 20 times.  The new version, now at South Street Seaport (the anti-East Village), is a deep disappointment. It has none of the energy or ambiance of the original. It's severely corporate (although the views from the outdoor seating are indeed fabulous), large screen TV's on the walls, & wildly overpriced; the small portions are barely share-able, and the service was lousy (we ordered one cocktail which was served after most of the appetizers had arrived and the waitperson had to be reminded, & one appetizer arrived after the main courses were served, again, after a reminder). The food itself was very good, but the menu is smaller and the variety was limited. Many of the menu items that brought us to the old location were gone and they refused to make anything that was not on the menu (which they would cheerfully do at the old spot).  Did I mention it was overpriced?  I would not go back.  David Chang lost a loyal Saam Bar customer with his move out of the East Village.
No comment

Popped in to the new no 7 on a weeknight this week and overall had a good meal, though I now know exactly what I'd do if I came back. While the cocktail list and cocktails themselves were fine, I'd grab your beer of choice or a classic cocktail and snag a seat at the bar. From there, I'd order the broccoli tacos (they pack a ton of flavor on their own but the add a few dashes of the sauce they'll bring out and it's a flavor explosion) and also a side of fries (as long as you like em McDonalds style). That's it - that's the order. If you absolutely must have a larger meal, I think the fried chicken sandwich was quite tasty. Tried the cheeseburger too but it was very minimalistic and frankly, very rare - didn't taste like much else than... meat. *shrugs*

I've been waiting for this to open for months.  So cute inside and has a real neighborhood feel.   Really good drinks, wine and beer selection. I did t eat but the menu seems limited which I think is smart since they just opened.   Looking forward to being a regular
The burger is the only thing that's good here. Very limited menu. Drinks are mediocre. The chicken sandwich was meh. And french fries just ok.
Still as good, if not better than ever. Great wine by the glass list, refreshed menu items (bologna was uniquely delicious), and killer, juicy fried chicken sandwich. Fries still in point!!

Welcome back, no. 7! This new/old spot is such a great addition to the neighborhood. We have so many good restaurants on Vanderbilt but have been sorely lacking an unfussy but elevated new American neighborhood spot. This checks all the boxes: food is great but not too pretentious or too expensive, and the cocktails are perfectly mixed. (I almost wept with joy when my watermelon mezcal drink wasn't sweet--why does everyone need to pour a pound of sugar into a watermelon cocktail?! no. 7 gets it.) We had no trouble walking in on a Saturday night but the place was doing brisk business. Super pleased to have them here and hope they're around for another 13+ years.

This is my favorite restaurant! The food and drinks are always fantastic, and the vibe is a perfect mix of relaxed and elegant. Plus, the staff is amazing!
No comment

No comment

We discovered this spot looking for ramen and glad we decided to try! Everything we had was super delicious- Ramen, crispy tuna - the shrimp tempura was a favorite! Highly recommend- staff was super friendly and great service!

Really not a fan of the chicken ramen here but the Chirashi bowl was good! Maybe err on the side of the sushi over the ramen. The takoyaki wasn't bad either. Currently BYOB. Nice to have another not too crazy expensive option in Hudson Yards!

I usually go to the Suram location on UWS, it's one of my favorite sushi spots. Happily stumbled across this new location a few weeks ago while looking for a snack in the Hudson Yards area. The interior is beautiful and spacious. The sushi was delicious and fresh. I like the spicy tuna roll and their special rolls (three and four) are also very good. Service was great - fast and attentive.

New place in the neighborhood, had to check it out. Cute decor. Attentive staff, especially during dinner rush. We love it when waiters know when to fill our (nearly) empty water glasses. The ramen was delicious, though I wish it was pork chasu (they only serve chicken). I did ask for no bamboo shoots, but I found two tiny ones in my bowl. The sushi was decent
No comment
Great food.  Great ambiance!  Excellent service!! From appetizers to dinner all was amazing

We had such a great dinner here. Walked in straight from checking into our nearby hotel and were seated right away (only 2 of us). Service was prompt, helpful and even jovial, which was appreciated. We eat sushi quite often, and the signature rolls Six and Eight were up to par, but the crispy rice dishes were the star of the meal! We were in and out as quickly as we needed but felt we could have lingered longer if we wanted. Solid choice that we would return to again.
Delicious ramen soup! Great and clean place to visit. Service was fabulous as always, will come back!

Suram is a great location for a casual lunch for a small group. The menu is relatively inexpensive and the service is great. Went with a large group and would not recommend that, but overall was very impressed with the ambiance and attention the wait staff gave to our group. Would go back in the future.

Top notch sushi, great pricing. Food was delicious and the service was spot on. Great vibe with a friendly staff. Great addition to the neighborhood. Looking forward to the opening of their event space for corporate events.

Reviewing here because my 1 star review on Google does not show up. Had the Rock Shrimp Tempura on a takeout order that we came to pick up. Took one bite and stopped eating because THEY DID NOT REMOVE THE POOP TRACT FROM THE SHRIMP. Absolutely disgusting. I live across the street and will now go out of my way to never return. FILTHY!!!

Wow, what an amazing place! This was some of the best ramen I have ever had. The ambience and decor of the interior was beautiful, the staff were all incredibly friendly. The broth of the ramen was so good I had to ask for an extra cup. The sushi was also fantastic, and they had some of the best crispy rice in the city. I am very fortunate to live so close to this new gem, and I will definitely be back for more!
No comment
Place is beautiful. Staff is so attentive. Food is on point. And so affordable. So nice to have this place so close. Will be a regular here

We ordered the rock shrimp, salmon fried rice, spicy tuna roll and the special roll 3. Overall it was extremely good and service was top notch. This is a new restaurant but we are so grateful it's in our neighborhood, we will definitely be back.

Great ramen and sushi! The wait was a little long but we got some hot tea to fight off the cold winds outside. The staff were all great and the sushi and ramen were delicious. Great vibes too, small dining room but it felt cozy! Will definitely go again if I'm in the area!

I live across the street and have been waiting for this location to open, and it did not disappoint! The interior is beautiful and calming, I forgot where I was for a second. The food was AMAZING. The quality of sushi was really great, the speed and attentive of service was also great. Best sushi you'll find in this direct area. OH and the best part - BYOB with no uncorking/service fee.
No comment
No comment

I've only been for drinks. I love the Bedstuy area, so it lends to the ambience of the bar. The bartender was very knowledgeable,and allowed me to sample a few spirits. The cocktails were all sensational. I'll need to come back to try the pizza, which came highly recommended.
No comment

Food and drinks are great here! We've been here a few times and love the simple menu. Good classic Italian food. Rarely is the service ever off. The backyard is cozy with heaters and cover. So many different kinds of spritz and the funghi pizza is our fav! So much flavors in the dough with perfect crispy crunch. So good!

Without reservations, we (a party of two) were delighted to sit and enjoy a delicious cauliflower soufflé appetizer, a very well made gluten free mushroom, artichoke, and olive pizza, and a couple of finely crafted Negroni cocktails. We really enjoyed the ambience, and sitting so close to the two-top beside us was not as uncomfortable or distracting as you might think. The soft lighting and the light music vibe was really perfect and exactly what we were hoping for. All of the ingredients tasted very high quality, and the service was all very nice and polite. We enjoyed our experience here very much, and we would return, especially for dessert which we did not have time to order. They gave us an hour and a half before the table was reserved for someone else. Just enough time to enjoy a second round of Negronis!

I love this place! Their Roman style pizza is so crisp and well made, and the Negroni are all amazing. Really reasonably priced and a super cute indoor and outdoor space. Highly recommend for a date night or just casual drinks at their beautiful bar! Super happy this place is in the neighborhood and that they made it though the pandemic.
No comment
No comment

I had the chance to visit bar Camillo on a weekend night to grab drinks with a friend. The bar itself is large with tons of seating. They also have a back area that also has more seating as well. When we arrived we were allowed to sit at two open high chairs at the bar. The bartenders here were super friendly and made each drink we ordered skillfully. I would recommend this spot to catch up with a friend or for a date night. It's a little bit of a walk from the subway but the vibes make it worth it!

They need more staff. Food & getting served takes too long. We never got the other drinks we ordered. & we have to stop the waiter in a hurry just to get served & needs met. 3 stars because great playlist & the Food & drinks were good when we did receive them.
Delicious cocktails, cool bartenders, and great atmosphere. We haven't tried the food yet but it smelled and looked delicious! Can't wait to come back here

10/10 would come back again. They have Inferno and Campari cocktails which is amazing. We ate the Formaggi and baked Cacio e Pepe which were exactly what we wanted, as we we feeling like a cheese feast. The wine and beer were also great, wine was on tap hope they have draft beer soon.

Went to Bar Camillo for the first time on a whim for dinner Wednesday night. Had never been before and it's a local spot I had walked by before so I wanted to give it a try. We arrived around 8:00 PM without a reservation and were seated within about 15-20 minutes. I thought it might be quiet on a Wednesday, but while we were waiting someone else asked for a table and we realized 3 other couples were waiting after us! We sat in the back which was cute and romantic. It rained heavily during the meal which actually added to the atmosphere since we were protected by the transparent roof! It was warmer in the backyard than the inside which also looked nice but not uncomfortable as they had fans throughout. My partner and I noticed that it seemed like maybe a server called out; there was one guy literally doing everything from hosting to grabbing drinks to serving food etc. He was a champ! Service was still reasonably paced and I just couldn't believe how good this guy was. Despite doing a million things at once I still felt like he provided personal attention and was easy to get a hold of, like when we wanted the check. Pizza was nice and thin and crispy and filling! Was it the best pizza I've ever had? No, not necessarily. But I liked it overall and enjoyed the service and atmosphere. I would return again with a reservation and try the pasta dishes in the future.

Not sure how I forgot to post this but y'all need to know where the universe is hiding great food. First off, let me say that hands down indoor dining is likely better at this place in both locations but the food makes the noise outside at both locations tolerable. The salad was incredibly low key and delicious.  The pizza crust, sauce, and toppings were all fresh and memorable for the flavor pallette. It was a good time....minus the noise from the cars and area.
Food is amazing. Wait staff is even better. It's such a wonderful place. Terry is the best human.

I really enjoy this place! The atmosphere and food are lovely. Our server Mia was phenomenal, she really made our dinner over the top! She was attentive, informative on the menu and friendly. We will be back, thanks Mia and bar camillo for a great experience.
Been to both their locations, food is great. Their brown spirit selections are excellent, the food is just banging. Pizzas are great but the goat I had so on point!

Idk who these people are leaving 5-star reviews but obviously they have never eaten food before. Salsiccia and greens plate was clearly cooked + seasoned in an underground natural salt deposit. Focaccia was just crusty pita bread with with old rosemary. Cacio e Pepe was served as TJ's Annies shells. I wasnt gonna leave a 20% tip but my gf yelled at me. Overall, my mouth feels more disrespected than Chris Rocks' during the oscars.
No comment
No comment

This restaurant makes me wished I lived in Bed Stuy just so I could have a reliable Italian spot with $10 negronis and reliable food! The pizza isn't my favorite, but it's sturdy and obviously they put some care into their toppings. Highlights for me were the negroni and lasagna. I always order the meatballs when I go to a restaurant like this and I'd say you can skip them. Price is too high for only three balls and they fell apart & just tasted like mixed up ground beef with no binder/cheese/seasoning.
No comment
Food is good, service is okay.  It's a nice neighborhood place but sadly the menu almost never changes so once you been there a few times, there's not a lot to keep one coming back.
No comment
No comment
No comment
Hidden gem in Bed Sty with better pizza than Saraghina or Ops!  Light crispy but with airy texture that is hard to describe. We had a margherita pizza and artichokes. Recommend all!
No comment

Bar Camillo was pretty good. Happy vibe. I tried Funghi Pinsa here and it was absolutely great. Service was very good and everybody working here was really nice and hospitable. Definitely will come back to this place always.
Excellent appetizers and pizza with a lovely atmosphere that is clean and friendly. The service is great and is a lovely addition to the neighborhood.
This place was great! We tried the meatballs and artichoke apps, both were great. We split a pizza and the pesto lasagna for dinner- both were also amazing! & the Negronis are a must.
Best Negroni's around! The drinks are amazing-and the staff are always so sweet to help my friends when they come visit. It's been such a sweet and fun experience every time I come here.

We wuz passin by this place that we had odered from before what I like about is different what my gurl likes cuz she knows more about it than me. This place is more than just pizza its like they have different italian foods. I like the pizza doe cuz they have it like the pizza magarita. My girl,likes the pasta and the lasagna.  and they got different beers to drink if u want. we sat outside and it was cool cuz its in bed-stuy.
The food is soooooooooo good. The pizza is fresh and tasty. There is a backyard patio and the delivery was on time with hot food.
Holy shit the food is flavorful and the service is friendly AF and the vibe is supreme
Ordered delivery off Caviar. They sent totally wrong order-tried to call no answer. What a joke! 0 stars!

Just a forewarning, service here tends to be slow but that is because everything is made to order including your coffee done in traditional pulled style and served in a bag or pouch. Their French toast is a must as is their ice coffee and anything pandan is definitely the way to go.
No comment

I've been visiting New York about 2-3 times every year to see family in Brooklyn so my adventures in the city are never alone and with predetermined stops. On this rare weekday morning, I had the opportunity to visit the city alone. I decided to stop at this small shop because I wanted some coffee and a quick bite to give me fuel for my steps. The nasi lemak awakened all of my taste buds in my mouth in the most wonderful and magnificent way that when I close my eyes now, I can still taste the pungent shrimp paste and crispy little fishes. It was incredibly satisfying, delicious, and magical!!! Love at fist bite. The dish was so powerful and good that it detracted me from weird smells that permeated from the restroom into the dining area. I'm not typically germophobic, but I knew instinctively that if I allowed my eyes and nose to do too close of an inspection at the surroundings, I would not have been able to enjoy the meal at all. The staff were friendly and efficient so that also balanced out the experience.

No comment
Busy coffee shop with small bites. Came on a weekend afternoon and there were no tables. Staff was kind. Ended up getting a coffee to go.
No comment

This is the spot if your looking to grab some quick flavorful lunch! I love malaysian food and this spot is pretty good! I ordered the nasi lemak, pan mee, pan dan bread, and a 100 plus as my refreshment. It was quick and delicious. definitely recommend it.
No comment

No comment
No comment
No comment

Reviewing Kopitiam when I'm not in NYC anymore is the biggest mistake!! Now I'm craving their kaya toast and I don't know where to get it in California!! I love their kaya toast, they packed the toast with homemade kaya. Not too sweet, definitely can taste the pandan. I love it! What I will also miss is their nasi lemak. It's a simple coconut rice with sambal ikan bilis, but why it tasted sooooooo good? My type of comfort food. I can eat this everyday. Chicken rice was good as well, but nasi lemak is the winner. Service was fast and friendly. Kuddos to the cashier/bartender!! He handled everyone with care considering how busy they were.

No comment

I was craving kaya toast and found this cute cafe that  serves all the traditional malaysian breakfast food. We got the laska, kaya butter toast and chicken rice to share and it was definitely a bit too much for two people. the food came out super fast and the kaya toast was definitely our favorite. It came with a thick layer of kaya jam and the bread was perfectly toasted. Also enjoyed the kopi here as well!
No comment
No comment

I came with a friend for Sunday dinner, and had to wait around 15 minutes for a table, as they have limited seating and no reservations. It's a no-frills cafe where you order at the register and grab a seat after. We sat at the bar/counter seating in the front, and there were some small tables that fit 2-4 diners in the center. I ordered the Nasi Lemak and Kaya Toast. The Nasi Lemak had a delicious sambal and tasted like a home-cooked meal. I loved the pandan coconut jam in the kaya toast, and wish they sold this as a separate item you could take home. Overall, flavorful, well-portioned, and reasonably priced Malaysian dishes in a casual dining environment. A Malaysian friend gave her stamp of approval for Kopitiam, so I take her word for authenticity!
No comment
No comment
No comment

A delicious little spot in china town! We came here with a few friends for brunch, and the food was both quick and fresh! I got the hokkien mee, cinnamon butter cake, and the tea with condensed milk. The tea latte was truly rich and luxurious, and the hokkien mee hit the spot with its spicy, shrimpy flavor in hot soup form. Overall highly recommend this place for a fun and unique meal!
No comment

The food here is okay, nothing amazing or as hyped up as other reviewers have said. Ordered the classic set with hainanese chicken and rice. The nasi lemak was average, not much of a coconut flavor in the rice (2/5). The kopi was literally just instant coffee and extra 50 cents for iced (why?). The hainanese chicken was very dry and the rice felt like it was left out for too long (1/5). The toast was probably the best (4/5). The food would have been fine, if it weren't for the awful attitude that the cashier had. Too busy chatting with her coworker and gave an attitude when taking the order, if she wanted a fight, go work for the WWE.

No comment

Something happened to their food quality + portion size. I came before in 2021 and ordered the white coffee and nasi lemak. I came in 2022 and reordered the same exact meal and the vibes were off. I cannot tell why this is happening to them. I don't mind paying for good food, but something was definitely off. Service was average and typical. Maybe it would be great for someone not experienced in Malaysian food. I'm not Malaysian personally, but can assume that if you are Malaysian or are very familiar with Malaysian food, the quality of the food here will not sit well with you.

Food was great, but very crowded and had to wait a decent time for seats. Seating was very tight and hard to maneuver, and pricing is also not soft per se, so overall takeouts might have been a better option...

No comment
No comment

This place was bustling Saturday for lunch! I'm not too familiar with Malaysian food but it seemed authentic. You order at the front and get a number. Someone comes up to you when you're waiting in line to point you to a table so there's no stress on finding the next person who leaves. I ordered the Char Kway Teow and it was delicious! I also saw people with drinks in bags and kaya toast on the menu. My plan is to try those next, and I'll definitely be back.

I love this place. One of my favorites. Not just the amazing big hearted owners, but the food has always been so heart warming and cozy. I always order a ton of bites. They have pretty decent portions so it is easy to over order. But you also just have to try everything! I love the variety. My favorite thing to do is get a coffee, kaya toast and a pandan chicken. It makes a fun little stop when walking anywhere. Grabbing lunch, I highly rec adding their soft boiled eggs to everything. They make a beautiful add to every dish. Whether it is hainan chicken rice or any of the noodle dishes wet or dry. Love love love. I also ordered this time a fish ball soup and chicken wings just to try them. Nothing particularly special about the fish ball soup but it is just a nice warm add for winter. A peppery broth that you can add noodles to if you want! If you love Malaysian home cooking or Malaysian street food, this is the spot.

It's a pretty casual place where you scan the menu from a QR code and order at the counter. Portions are a little small but the food tastes good. I liked the kaya toast and the tok tok mee. The nasi lemak was good but I have had better. The drinks come in a cute little bag which reminded me a little of getting bagged drinks in Malaysia. Overall, it's worth a visit to try.

There was a small wait coming here but it was worth it. The staff was great and everything seemed organized despite how busy it was. The interior was very cozy. This was my first time having hokkien mee and Malaysian coffee. I am a huge noodle lover so having both egg and vermicelli noodles in one dish was awesome. There is plenty of protein since you get shrimp, really flavorful pork belly, and a whole egg. I wonder if there may have been some type of belacan or shrimp paste that gave the pork broth a slight funky umami flavor. I wish there were more vegetables though. The packaging for the bek kopi is so fun. The kopi was not too strong and not too sweet. I would definitely order both of these things again but I need to try more things on the menu!

Great lunch spot! Came here on a Sunday afternoon and the place was decently busy. Had to wait around a bit to get a table for a group of 3 but didn't wait very long. We ordered a bunch of stuff to share which I'd recommend since there are lots of tasty things to try on their menu. The Nasi Lemak, Pandan Chicken, Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodles, and Tok Tok Mee were all pretty good. My favorite was the Oh Chien (oyster omelette). So good! Also, their Kaya Butter Toast was divine. The kaya jam and that perfectly toasted bread was incredible. And of course, I got an iced coffee (Bek-Kopi) which was great. Worth the trip!

I have a bit of mix feelings about this restaurant. The first thing is that I loved the Kayan toast. However, it would have been better if eveyrthing was spreaded more evenly. The first few bites I took from the toast was a glob of butter but because of the pandan flavor of the Kayan, I instantly fell in love with this spread. I also got the Nasi lemak which was  super delicious. This was my first time having Nasi lamak so I started to crave for more of this dish ever since I tried it from here. I also got the kopi coffee which honestly was not the greatest. I felt like it was a bit too bitter and watered down. I also got the Pulut tai tai and the Pulut inti. It was pretty heavy and sweet. I didn't realize how great the combo is with the sticky rice and the Kaya jam. As for the kuih talam, I felt like it was better off not having the sea salt taste. The prices are a bit on the higher end but overall I would probabaly only come back for the Nasi lemak.

Sooo good. I got the butter kaya toast, and the pineapple buns and a kopi. Made me miss singapore so much
No comment

Yummy Malaysian! Kopitiam has been on my list for a while as I love Southeast Asian flavors. We came on a weekend for lunch and luckily snagged a table inside. The restaurant is pretty small so you might need to wait a while for a table. Portions are pretty small, so it's a good idea to order quite a few things and share. My absolute fave was the Kaya Butter Toast, which was fluffy and sweet. The Nasi Lemak was tasty as well and came with a delicious sambal. The Pan Mee was good too, but I felt like the flavors were more one-dimensional so I might get something else next time. Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodles were a a cool noodle dish with lots of creamy spicy flavors, great for hot days! Don't forget to order a side of Coconut Rice to soak up all the yummy flavors.

As a homesick Singaporean, and the Pan Mee was the closest alternative I have found to Ban Mian! The teh ping (iced teas) are cute in their packaging, and would be 90% close to what teh pings at home are like. The kueh salat was fantastic too.
No comment
No comment

We first went in 2019, after it was named Bon Appetit's Best 10 Restaurants of the year, and it didn't disappoint. I haven't been able to travel back to New York with the pandemic, but it was always one I wanted to visit again. After recently going back, we tried a few new items along with the classic Nasi Lemak. It was just as I good as I remembered and can't wait to go again in the future.
Hole in the wall with amazing food and ambience!! Great flavors and spices. Be prepared to squeeze into whatever table/space you can find.
No comment

What a fantastic spot for Malaysian food! Came here with a friend and had a fantastic time! They are first come first serve, no reservations! They have indoor and outdoor seating. Food is basically small plates to share. We ordered almost 6 items and all were amazing especially the wings, cold spicy noodles. Also had the special calamansai and lychee drinks!
No comment

Went in with high expectations because of all the reviews but was disappointed with the food... the beef is more chewy than my bicycle tires, the condensed milk on the milk toast seems to be mixed with water making the toast soggy. Chicken wing is dried like thanksgiving turkey and I bit on egg shells on the oyster egg dish... Even when I cook at home, I make sure there's no egg shells in the food... I don't know how they have a 4 star average review. I can only assume they are either fake reviews or friends supports. Won't be coming back even if they pay me

Cute little authentic store, although service is not the best. Kaya toast was really good, and the pan Mee as well. The cold sesame noodles are not great (very watery)

This place is FIRE. I recommend doing family style. The plates are deceiving because they look like small portions, but they're actually generously loaded with food. Very carb heavy, so be prepared for that! Everything was absolutely divine though. Flavorful, cooked well, great textures, and a wide selection of sweet and savory foods. Everything was plated nicely. Fun drink, snack, and dessert options as well. I'd recommend everything I ordered (which is hopefully pictured), but my favorites were probably kaya (pandan + coconut) butter toast and oh chien (oyster omelette). My first time having Malaysian food and it was an absolute treat. Would love to come back!
No comment

For our short trip in NYC, I happened to stop by at Kopitiam for dinner. I have ordered Nasi Lamak, cold Sesame Spicy noodle, Muah-Chee, Teh and Coffee. I am pleased to say that the price is good for the dish size and Muah-Chee is the best I have eaten besides from Asia. It brought back my childhood memories. Their Teh Tarik and Kopi are also solid. I'm glad I have tried Kopitiam on this trip.

Busy little spot in Chinatown that serves up some fantastic drinks! They are traditionally served and it adds some a great touch to the overall experience. Yet to try food here but it looks amazing so I will definitely be back! Overall fantastic
Unexpectedly found this place. Pretty good. Flavors are interesting. The dessert on the other hand was a little weird for me. Mainly like jello. I would recommend here to try. Foods good.

Overall pretty good. The Pan Mee broth was flavorful and noodles were chewy. The Hainanese chicken was fragrant, and the rice was quite aromatic with the pandan leaves. Wish the portions were a tad bit bigger for the price.

Every time I get into Manhattan, this stop would always be on my list for good authentic Southeast Asian grub! Love everything here! Everything is a must try down to  every drink on their menu! I am so glad it's still standing post pandemic!

We got the Nasi Lemak. Reasonably priced, filling and tasty. I wish they would have included a bit more of the sauce; 1 small container wasn't quite enough.

Their tapioca omelette (don't remember the proper name) is very good. My friend had one of their spicy shrimp soups (also don't remember the proper name of the dish) and he said it was ok too. And most importantly the prices are great.

Have been trying to come here for a while and I'm soooo glad I did. The food was SOOO good! 10/10 highly recommend the Criss Cross 'Shrooms'! Amazingly delicious! The Sesame Noodles and the Sago Gula Melaka we're good too! I ordered 4 dishes just for myself  I'll sure try their whole menu! The restaurant was not big and only accept party sizes smaller than 5 during Covid. Understandable. Try their food! You'll like it!

Really lovely shop near Chinatown with a wide selection of Malaysian dishes. I've tried several of their coffees and every one of them is great. Kopi Tarik is my favorite but Bek Kopi is good for a milder option with milk. I also love how they come in sealed bags so very transportable. Nasi Lemak is usually my go-to order at any Malaysian place (yes, basic is my middle name). The one at Kopitiam is decent but not my favorite. The coconut flavor is on the subtler side. The fried anchovies and peanuts were more chewy than crispy. The water spinach was nice and came in a generous portion considering the price.
Authentic food esp if you're missing Singapore. The muah chee, kuih talam, Pulut enti were spot on! Would definitely go back. They should add chwee kuih!

A cute place to stop by. Unfortunately I only got to try their coffee which was delicious! They have food and pastries too, so I'm excited for next time. Their service was quick!
The food tastes good the first few bites, and then became too greasy and salty and I couldn't finish it. Good for trying different dishes and sharing with a group.

Everything there is just way too sweet, and yet the sugar toast is not sweet at all? The food was okay but way over priced for such a small portion in Chinatown.... I don't think the buzz is well worth it.... I prefer to go to those other Malay food place in Chinatown for real authentic Malay food.... As a fellow traveler who use to live in Malaysia..... not authentic....
I went with my Malaysian friend here and had the Nyonya kuih... not so great. Actually his opinion was much more negative. Suffice to say, we didn't enjoy the desserts here.

It's a cute little place with yummy dishes. It can get crowded and chaotic but the staff was nice. Thank you

Came here for lunch with a friend on a Tuesday. We ordered the oh chien (oyster omelette), kaya toast, otak otak, pan mee (anchovy noodle soup) and pulut panggang. Everything was really good with authentic flavors. Our favorites were the oyster omelette and pulut panggang. We were really full after everything (the oyster omelette was huge). Will definitely come back to try other dishes!

My favorite Malaysian/Singaporean food haunt in NY. Reminds me of home. Bought the ikan bilis & sambal belachan home.

No comment

This Malaysian place is spectacular. I really love the Asian cafe feel, order at the counter and the staff brings out the food. This place has lots of small dishes which is great so I could try as much as I Can. Their drink menu is an extensive list of milk tea, coffee and milo mix creations. I highly recommend try the weekly and weekend special if you can because you may not catch it again for a while. The kueh chap was so fragrant with the five spice but also such a light dish even with the fried pork belly. If you love flat noodles you definitely have to try it. The kaya toast is a must at Malaysian places and pairs well with a coffee or milk tea. What I like about this place is that their menu doesn't have the typical Malaysian dishes you may look for at a restaurant. It has the true everyday food of Malaysian people.

This place is like a little piece of Singapore. I love the kaya butter toast - that is my favorite and they had the condensed tea. If I am from NYC, I would come here every morning but I will definitely be coming back to try other foods. I recommend coming here if you like Singapore food
Friendly service. We ordered our food at the counter and then sat down on a table and clear our table when we were done. Outdoor seating available. The food was okay and reasonably priced.

Save your money. Not authentic Malaysian food at all! Very disappointing! Don't believe the five star rating. If you are Malaysian do not eat there.

Kopitiam was great! They have limited outdoor seating at the moment (first come, first serve) but my boyfriend and I were able to grab a table after waiting a bit. We shared the Kaya butter toast, Malaysian style French toast (milo), Nasi lemak and Iced bandung. Favorite dish was the Nasi lemak. The tea was good, but the one at Grace Street is better.

Absolutely incredible noodles and other fare. Spicy but not too much, a great place for a day date.

The toast with pandan jelly is out of the world!!!!!! I literally dream of it! Also had the pandan chicken and coconut rice (best coconut rice besides mine)

I appreciate the owner took time to investigate the issue of the missing orders and provided the refund to me.  I understand restaurants are having tough time to get quality workers due to shortage of staff.  I really hope things will improve hereon.
The inside vibes are so cute, and the food presentation is even cuter! A great foodie spot with authentic Malaysian cuisine.

My friend got very sick immediately after eating hainanese chicken yesterday. We let the staff know about what happened but they didn't offer any kind of support, care, apology or even refund for the dish that made my friend very ill. And they asked where his dish was and took it to the kitchen. And we didn't hear anything from them after. It was a very disappointing and even scary experience, and I do not plan to go back as I do not feel safe eating there. And staff didn't seem to care about their customers at all.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place so much. I always order the Nasi Lamek and its perfect every time. Their Ikan Bilis and sambal are always such a perfect balance of salty, crispy and spicy and I love their coconut rice with it. Its so great! I also ordered the garlic water spinach (must get), Hainanese Chicken, Kaya toast, and peanut mochi. Our order was to-go so the kaya toast i imagine would have been better fresh but it was still amazing. Who doesnt love buttered toast with coconut pandan butter inside. The star for me was the peanut mochi. The texture of their mochi is stellar and i could eat that everyday!!

Went in with decent expectations because of all the reviews but was extremely disappointed with the food as a fellow Malaysian. The pictures for the food from this restaurant they are probably zoomed in 10 times to make it look presentable. Don't let them fool you. Price is obscene for the amount of food, one plate of their chow guay teoh is probably 1/4 portion (or less) of a full dish from any other Malaysian restaurant. Nasi lemak portion was disappointing, even the original nasi lemak wrapped in a pandan leaf back in Malaysia is way bigger size than that (cost 4 times less). Their signature milo French toast let me WARN you, stay far away from that no matter how unique it sounds to you because it is NOT worth trying. The French toast is drenched, some parts of the toast were burned and didn't taste like milo at all, the whole presentation just look sad and soggy. The cashier staffs seem like they were clueless about the orderings at all time. I don't know how they receive 4 stars because I felt generous giving them one star (After spending a whole $130 with family members in this restaurant we concluded the only thing that's worth a star would be their drinks (mediocre at best) Seek everywhere else for Malaysian food because this place is just not it. It was a shame for them to call this Malaysia Traditional food, none of the food quality or QUANTITY are even close to a traditional Malay place. Take my advice or you will pay dearly for it no pun intended.

Overhyped and gimmicky. Had a line outside the restaurant when we arrived for lunch (took that as a good sign.. must be good if there are people waiting to get in!). Oddly though, even though there was a line outside, there were also plenty of empty tables. Anyway, we walk in, and the waitress asks if we want to dine in. We said ok, and then she said it would be a half hour wait. I told her we'll just grab some takeout then. We got on the line to order food. Wasn't really a huge wait, but felt a bit unorganized. We got to the front of the line and ordered.. the lady working the cashier had to talk to us through some super old intercom system (not sure why, since she was like 2 feet away from us). Could not understand a word coming through the intercom (again, they probably just put that awful intercom in there for that gimmicky street food feel). The lady finally pulled the intercom away from her face and just spoke to us directly, and I could understand her crystal clear! Then she asked us if we wanted to take it away or dine in? Huh? Dining in was an option???? The first waitress we saw told us it would be a half hour wait! Anyway, since we had the option to dine in, we just did that. Paid the cashier, got a number, and found an open table by the window. The food came rather quickly. Everything tasted mass produced and made without any love. The Hainan chicken was dry and had zero flavor. How can dark meat chicken be dry? Everything else was forgettable. They served the drinks in ziploc pouches instead of cups... again, gimmicky and probably unnecessarily environmentally unfriendly. When we were done, we had to bus our own tables (even though we tipped at the register already... but whatever, that's fine.. it's important to tip the staff regardless). Even bussing our tables felt like a gimmick. They want to have the street food vibe, but they are charging Manhattan sit-down restaurant prices. Have no issue with paying more for good quality food, but this wasn't good food. Oh, but on the bright side, you get flies for free! There were flies all over the dining area. Hate to see what type of health code violations go on in the kitchen. Didn't finish our drinks, so brought them with us. Went back to our car, and realized that cars here have cup holders and not ziploc bag holders. Ugh.

Really cute Malaysian cafe with some very solid food options in a very casual setting. I had the tok tok mee, they do the dry noodle version of this dish and  it definitely hit the spot. Kaya toast is also really good here, honestly a pretty simple dish but toast with coconut-pandan jam is always great. Beef rendang  was pretty bad though, feels like a home-cooked braised dish in the bad way. Turns out slow braising beef does make it tender up to a certain extent, if you over-do it then the beef will end up dry and stringy which is what happened here. The curry itself tasted pretty good but if that dish was all that I ordered, I would have probably given the place 2 stars. As it stands though, I feel the place does a great job at bringing Malaysian cafe culture and street food to NYC just stay far away from the beef rendang. Only other annoyance is that the place is extremely popular and they don't do reservations so expect to wait a while.

Pretty good homemade tasting Malaysian food in the Chinatown/Lower East Side neighborhood on East Broadway ( there's a Citibike rack across the street next to Seward Park .) We got the Sotong Goreng appetizer which is Calamari but it's a lot of little tiny squids with dipping sauces. Also the Pulut Panggang which is sticky rice with shrimp paste. I'd say the squid was better (and I'd get potato curry puff if they had it that day but they didn't.) I had the Nasi Lemak which is a dry anchovies and peanut over rice and is the national dish of Malaysia. Definitely mix the sambal on the rice ! My friend got Tok Tok Mee which is chewy noodles with shrimp and pork and he liked that. I also had Calamansi ade which taste like lemonade. Best thing though is the Pulut Tai Tai which is a not too sweet dessert of blue sticky rice with Kaya jam made from coconut! Delicious. I wish I had got more than one. That was $3.75 and wrap in banana leaf. The peanut mochi is warm and good on a cold day but it's enough for 3 or 4 people to share because it's so rich so be aware! I'd recommend this place. Tasty food and good prices. No alcohol though.

Its kaya toast was not bad, but not mind-blowing, either. Maybe I am more used to modernized cooking of kaya toast. Its kaya toast and coffee had a rustic flavor... which was not bad, but, for me, seemed to lack something of sophisticated touches. And.. it would be great if they paid more attention to the general physical or hygienic cleanliness.

Kopitiam is a cozy little place in east village. I got the Kopi Tarik (white coffee) and the Pandan chicken triangles. The coffee was the perfect amount of sweet and was amazing quality. The chicken was cooked and seasoned perfectly. I went for coffee + snacks but will definitely be back for breakfast sometime soon.
Incredible and I can't wait to go back. The white coffee is out of this world. An amazing way to pretend I'm traveling and the sweetest staff. Cute branding ^.^

The food was pretty good here! My favorite was the Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodles, which were really yummy and a good level of spice. The pandan chicken tasted pretty good, but it's definitely very rich in flavor so it can be pretty filling. It is a bit sweet (probably from the pandan). This place is BOMB and makes legit Singaporean food that is super cheap and tasty on top of its authenticity. We got the nasi lemak, the kuih salat, the pan mee, and the otak otak. The nasi lemak is the most popular for a reason; super yummy with the dried anchovies - and honestly enough to split between two people. We were full after just splitting that alone. The pan mee noodles were also super flavorful and not too salty; however, maybe because we waited a while and got it to go, the noodles all stuck together. The soup itself though was very good - so I would recommend eating the soup first if you order it to go. The otak otak is definitely spicy and not in a traditional way; it has very strong herbs. We didn't get this with rice which was a mistake since, again, the herbs are very strong so the rice would have been good to cut it back a little while still allowing you to enjoy the strong flavors. Last but not least, the kuih salat was a nice dessert to end on - not overly sweet and light. Definitely going to come back here if I can!

I want to start my review by saying this place is so amazing and it is a must try! I came here because the menu looked interesting and I was unfamiliar with the items on it, so I wanted to try it out. We got the kway chap, kaya butter toast, and a curry puff to eat. The curry puff had a decent amount of spice and was very thick inside, it was delicious. We also got the kaya butter toast to try, which was made with such soft milk bread and a flavorful butter. The mixture of pandan and coconut flavor inside was so tasty and super light on the stomach. For my entree, I got the kuay chap which was wide noodles with eggs, tofu, pork belly and a dark soy sauce soup. First off,  I have never tried anything like this, but it is so delicious and I would definitely have it again. The noodles were so soft and they have a generous amount of toppings. As for the service, the staff was so friendly and helpful when it came to recommendations. I would definitely come back here and try some other stuff on the menu.

Kopitiam brings back fond memories of my Singaporean mother making me classic breakfast staples such as Malaysian Kopi Tarik, Teh Tarik, or even a cold Milo drink. It also helps that the interior is set up exactly like a classic Singaporean hawker stall complete with the colorful chairs and walls. Aside from the aforementioned drinks, we also got the classics such as the Prawn mee and Hainanese chicken. The Prawn Mee was amazing, bursting with shrimp flavor and coated with a generous heaping of fried shallots - even on a hot summer day, I could not help but slurp down all of the broth. While the Hainanese chicken was prepared in the traditional style, I couldn't help but notice that the green scallion and ginger sauce accompaniment was a bit watered down and lacking in flavor. In addition, the chicken rice balls were over cooked, causing the rice to be a bit on the mushier side. Even with that in mind, I am still willing to forgive Kopitiam for so faithfully taking me down memory lane with their other traditional dishes we tried such as the ondeh ondeh (sweet potato rice balls) and Kaya toast. I am looking forward to my next visit where I can hopefully bring my mom as well!

So good!!!! Came here after work one day with some friends due to several recommendations I've gotten about eating here. Though some of the things I wanted to try were sold out, what I did manage to try was amazing and I'll definitely be back to try what I couldn't last time. I got the Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodles, Kaya Toast, and Lobak. Everything was SOOO good. The kaya toast is amazing - it's the fluffiest slightly sweet bread with this amazing cream between the slices. I could eat that for days. The savory dishes were great as well - bold flavors, well portioned, well priced

Pretty neat place. Now that Kopitiam is at a new location (albeit a little far), there is sufficient seating. The various coffee concoctions are great, the desserts are authentic, and the drinks are fun.
Small dish portion. Not a good place to go if you are starving. I found the dishes very salty. Won't come back.
Delicious every time. I've eaten here pre-Covid and have also gotten take out since... amazing food either way. Definitely get the butter toast.

Wow this spot is NOT to be missed. The Kaya Jam Toast is soft, spongey, and flavorful and I kept going back for more. The chicken is fall off the bone tender. The rice to complement it, shaped into the most delicious little balls, was ideal for popping right into your mouth! Their most popular dish Nasi Lemak with coconut rice is so comforting. We weren't really hungry, so ordered the savory sesame noodle to share. I really enjoyed it! It's oily as you'd expect, but good flavor and the noodles were great. I also got the iced coffee with condensed milk (they can put in less condensed milk if you don't want it that sweet) which was solid. Girl who took our order was really sweet and helpful without being intrusive, and we got our food fast. Overall good experience and wouldn't mind coming back to check out other things, but the menu is small and the space is very cramped (smaller than my studio apt and not super comfortable either - just 4 stools next to shallow tables by 2 walls) - so if you have the option / somewhere to go to eat it, would opt for take-out.

I grew up in Malaysia so I was really excited to come but they didn't have great options, and half the options I wanted they weren't even able to serve because they were out of oil. We got the kaya toast, nasi lemak and chicken jerky buns and they were mediocre. I'm incredibly upset by my experience here.
The food was amazing and there were many good options! They also had very good Malaysian coffee. Staff was friendly and polite. Would recommend visiting.
Came here for a light breakfast. The food, presentation, and service was great. This is a cute, friendly place and I smiled when I saw the restroom signs 'Human' and 'Whatever.' Everyone is welcome.

Decided to check out this Malaysian spot in my neighborhood. If you are into savory breakfast foods, this is a place for you. I was pleasantly surprised by the rice bowl with peanuts, cucumbers, and hard boil egg. The coffee is also special. Super sweet and comes in juice pouch. Overall good experience and some new flavors for my palette.

SO GOOD!!! My craving level for nasi lemak is pretty much always set to 1000, so when my sister suggested breakfast at this spot, my hopes were already pretty high. The nasi lemak was fantastic, with a generous helping of anchovies and a really fragrant coconut rice. We also got the kaya toast (delicious, if a little over toasted), and the water spinach with sambal which was a pleasant surprise - what it lacked in presentation it more than made up for in taste. The whole menu looked amazing, I definitely hope to be back and try more soon!

Everything here is delicious including the coffees. Definitely get the nasi lemak and the soft mochi with the peanuts and coconut. Get here early to get a seat. They also start running out of items by noon.

Honestly upset I didn't find out this place existed earlier. It is adorable and homey. I had the kaya toast which I didn't know I've been missing all my life?? Why has no one told me about this delicious concoction? Far superior to any overpriced avocado toast even in its most simple, unadorned form. I also had the noodles, which were chewy and mildly spicy. It was a tad too salty for my personal liking but overall still delicious. I tied everything together with a cup of white coffee which was just the right balance of bittersweet and very smooth and aromatic. A great place for a snack or a brunch stop! My new favorite in my 'all time hits'.

Huge fan of this place! The nasi lemak is delicious - perfect combo of sweet and savory. I don't know Malaysian food well and have asked for recommendations the last few times I've been here. Each dish has hit it out of the park. Only request is that they extend their hours! Since they bill themselves as serving coffee and treats (in addition to incredible meals), it'd be great if they were open from 8/9 AM onward.
No comment

The pink decore payphone and rustic storefront caught my eye and drew me in. Was looking for a place to grab a quick cup of coffee. The menu there was certainly authentic. I took a shot and ordered the Kopi-Ghee with a honey comb cake. The coffee took only a few short minutes and was brought to my table in a very cute tea cup. The coffee was so delicious!!!!! Only I just wish there was more of it. And for+ $4 you'd think that there would be. Maybe if I ordered it to go? All in all this is a beautiful location. If I'm in the neighborhood again I could see myself splurging on another shot of coffee.

Pandan Chicken looks beautiful but the chicken was too salty. Don't know if the leaf wrap on the outside adds anything to the dish since it was deep fried. All types of cuisines whether it is Spanish, Chinese and etc, the leaf wraps are boiled or steamed and the process added flavor and holds the flavor inside. This wrap is partially wrapped. The sweet and sour dipping sauce is great though.  Pan Mee was just ok and it wasn't what I expected. It tasted more like mediocre Japanese soup and not Malaysian at all.  I've been dining in tons of Malaysian restaurants for over 15 years.
No comment
No comment

Came here with my girlfriend at around 11 on a Sunday for a late breakfast. We were a little groggy from the night before having been woken up at 2 a.m. by our party boy neighbor and his party pals but the wonderful flavors and caffeine concoctions woke me right up. We both had cham, a coffee/tea/condensed milk combo. A little more bitter than you'd think, as the tannins in the tea really come through in a big way but still quite good. I started with a curry puff to whet the appetite. The gf said it could do with more salt but I thought it was good as is. We then shared the peanut sugar french toast and the fish ball soup, both of which absolutely slapped. The french toast had that floofy fluff I crave and all of it was covered in the peanut-y goodness. Really good. Not as sweet as I was expecting but I mean that in a good way. Soup was excellent, with the peppery hot broth served boiling hot. Absolutely loved this meal. Will definitely be coming back to try everything else.

No comment

The place is very small with limited seats. Went up to the display and placed my order, menu selections are mostly for breakfast items. Got their popular Morning Glory Purple sticky rice with toasted coconut, thousand layer thin (beehive) cakes, and also tried their hand toss coffee. I'm wasn't too impressed with their cup of joe since they added condense milk in there; has a sour taste to it. The sticky rice tasted good without being too overwhelming. The thousand layer cakes was very small and thin, but tasted so  cinnamon-ly good. Good recommendations fellow Yelpers
Excellent service, all the staff is helpful and friendly. Good food. Cozy. Located close to subway train station.

Unlike some reviewers I didn't have any issues with customer service. They make it upfront that you bus your own tables. When we had questions about the menu etc the waiters were very helpful. The food however was underwhelming. It's not a SE Asian restaurant where there are lots of mains offering. Which is ok. But what they offer on the limited menu should be absolutely perfect and they were mostly ok. Nothing was bad at all. Just all very mediocre :( there was a line and we waited about 15min for lunch on a Saturday.

Visiting NYC and checked this place. Wanted to see if the food is close to home food. Yup!! Milo and kaya toast is da bomb especially with the teh Tarik. Brought back some great memories of pasar malam yummies. Looking forward to the next visit.

Sadly I really wanted to like this place, the food was tasty, however the customer service and managing of orders is terrible. They forgot two of our ordered entrees, and we sat their for almost 45 mins, however when we brought it up they simply shrugged it off. Not a cool way to treat super hungry people in a city with so many other competent restaurants. Will never come here again.

Lots of dishes that are unusual in NY and quite tasty. Nothing really blew my mind but along with the charming, low-key atmosphere and wide selection of what feel like very homey dishes, I definitely recommend this spot.

Someone recommended this place for me to try so i went.  First impression is that oh man, this place is so small and there is only 4 chairs... how am i going to eat??? beside that, i tried their tea, spicy cold noodle and sticky rice... OH MY GOD!!! they are so good... Especially the spicy cold noodle... it's very refreshing, a little spicy b/c of the spicy oil and also the sesame oil smell soon good... HIGHLY RECOMMENDED... and the tea is soo soo good... the guy literally "pull" the tea to mix it and he even taste test it before serving us.  A must try!! and I will definitely go back for more...

Great I got the lobak which was recommended and it was super tasty! I also got a curry puff (decent) and a Kopi-ghee (felt like at 4.25 it's a bit overpriced for a regular black coffee, granted with ghee so maybe it's one of those expensive alternatives). I've been to Kopitiam when it just opened and had a hole in the wall location, was super excited about the menu (so many options and so hard to decide!) Definitely coming back, just minus one star for the slightly overpriced ghee coffee.

Amazing Malaysian snacks.. first time tried it. Love them all !!!

I had the kaya toast with the soft boiled eggs and it was amazing! For beginners, dip your toast in the yolk, it amplifies the taste so much. The toast by itself is good but not filling, but with the eggs? AMAZING! The coffee was done really well, strong but smoo

Got the Pan Mee and it was decent. The portion came in really small and it was quite pricey. The environment there is nice and relaxing, it is also clean so that's a plus! I also tried their Nasi Lemak and it was very delicious. This is definitely a place to visit when looking for a snack, or a light meal. I ended up going back to the counter to re order because the portion size was very small. They also have drinks like and soy milk (my favorite). Worth a try, but can be expensive if frequently visited.

The staff is amazing. The food is delicious. There are wonderful precautions put in place for COVID.

Nostalgia of home. 4/5. Good place to come in for comfort food. Prices are a bit too high for the small portion size though.

Restaurant/cafe with a very cute vibe - I liked the use of ingredients or old tins as part of the decor. I ordered the nasi lemak and a black sesame almond milk drink. I enjoyed the food for the most part especially the spicy relish, although I didn't like that the boiled egg was cold (maybe that's normal for the dish but I'm not a fan). I also found a small pebble in the anchovies! The staff were very nice when I pointed it out to them and offered to make me a new dish, but they definitely need to do some more careful cleaning of the fish. I wanted to like it more because it's a very nice vibe and I liked the menu options but there are still some details they need to work out. I'd like to visit again and try a different dish.

While it may be a little bit out of the way for many, this is truly a lovely cafe. The ambiance is really cheery and clean and spacious. They have real menus (thankfully, with descriptions of the dishes,) and you can have a sit-down meal here or just get coffees. I ordered the Pulut tai tai and the kaya toast. The pulut tai tai was a real winner. It was beautiful and simple and the perfect portion size. However... by the time I got to my kaya toast maybe I was a little full. It was nice, but the kaya part of the toast was really sweet and it would have been fine with half as much kaya jam. Anyway, I definitely want to come back.

Kaya jam bussin. Must try Tok Tok Mee and kaya toast!!

Was visiting the city with my friend.  We both live in US States where there's limited access to Malaysian food.  We both ordered Pan Mee (my #1 comfort food from back home).  The taste transported us back home.  Very flavorful broth.  We also ordered some delicious kuih.  Highly recommended this place.

Came here after reading the Eater blog for being one the top rated breakfast spots in NY but was not impressed. We arrived around 11am on  Monday and there was no wait. It's a self serve restaurant so you take a number and they bring you the food. The food itself was pretty good, we ordered the Nasi Lemak, Kaya toast and duck tongue. First time eating Nasi lemak, it's interesting and different, pretty much fried/dried little fish (anchovies?) with nuts over rice with a side of cucumber and hot sauce. I have no idea what this is supposed to taste like since I've never had Nasi lemak but I don't think I would order this again. The Kaya toast was jgood, I was expecting more butter, it had a decent amount of the pandan coconut jam. Lastly the duck tongue was pretty flavorful, with the right amount of crisp. I've only ever had the duck tongue at dim sum spots but I don't remember so many bones. Honestly I don't know what all the rave is about. I would come back if I was in the area but definitely wouldn't come out of my way to eat here.

I have not touched a lot of Malaysian food, but it was the most enjoyable of recent restaurants. Comfort food to feel street food was splendid, and composition which could taste various was good, too.

Wow...we are super impressed. This place is amazing with some great vegetarian options. We had a spicy noodle soup and a bowl of rice with anchovies, and some sticky rice desserts. All of them were good. Try it out!
No comment

My new favorite place whenever I'm missing Singaporean food! The runny boiled eggs were an excellent start to brunch and the pork belly pan mee ($12.50) did not disappoint. I'm excited to return for the rest of their menu!
No comment

Came here for a quick lunch. It has a fast food feel where you order at the register and they bring the food to you at a communal table. I would discard the lack of atmosphere for good food but it also fell short here. The best thing we ordered was the Nasi Lemak. The wings were average. We also had some noodle soup that was bland. The peanut mochi dessert was good but Hao's noodle's rendition blows it out of the water. Will not return.

First let me say the two pictures are from two different days. Though the bowls look small, don't let it fool you; there's a lot of food. I struggled both times to finish the food It's a self-serve/ almost cafeteria-style spot. Let's talk about food and what I recommend. I REALLY liked the Kaya Butter Toast and Pulut Tai Tai (sticky rice), they had the same pandan coconut jam that made me fall in love with them. Kaya Butter Toast was crispy but soft and fluffy. Pulut Tai Tai with the jam was really good, but it would've so much better of the sticky rice was a bit warm and a little softer. My next favorite thing was the Curry Puffs and Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodles, if you can handle spicy I think you should give it try. The curry puff was stuffed with a lot of spicy and creamy curry and crispy crust made it delicious. Chilled Spicy Sesame Noodle was oily (chili oil), but I think the salted egg added more flavors and the cucumbers cut down the oiliness and made it taste very fresh. This dish would be good for summer. The next two dishes, I would only recommend if you like dried or fermented fish. Pan Mee and Pulut Panggang were not bad, but not my favorite either because I am not the biggest fan of dried anchovies and shrimp. Last but not least, Fish Ball Soup! The fishball tasted fresh and the soup is a tiny bit spicy, which was unexpected.
No comment

Penang Chicken was so juicy every bite and pairs perfectly with the sauce on the side. Their Muah Chee is a must try for peanut and mochi lovers- It's soft, gooey and practically melts in your mouth. I wish they had their lychee rose available though... gives me another reason to come back and try more things~

Love the mua Chee, the original with peanuts. Went back there couple times and always got the mua Chee. I tried the nasi lemak and pan mee, they were good and very simple. If you want something simple and taste good, try them all. The place is definitely so much larger than the original kopitiam and so glad that they moved to bigger space with people seatings.

I've been living in New York since 1994. There have so many Malaysian restaurants open and close in the past, some are ok, some are good but no place which you feel they will take you back to south east Asia. When you walked in Kopitiam, you will sense it by the smell. All the food are extremely delicious and authentic. Fish ball egg noodle soup, stick rice dessert. You can't just pretend you can make it. Place is a bit tight but come and go fast so you won't wait too long. Stuff are so cute and friendly. Love the energy. Go

We are always here. Good breakfast food. The nasi lemak and Kaya toast are our favorites.

The nasi lemak was amazing! One of the best just like in Malaysia. The fish ball noodle soup is also good! The oyster omelette was very salty and it tasted like they cooked it with belacan which was unusual. The kaya toast was not that great as I expected better. It was thick, soft and a little on the heavy side. The desserts are not bad. Overall it's pretty much self service from ordering to cleaning up after you eat. The staffs are friendly and accommodating. The environment was a bit chaotic as it's very small and a lot of people. The stools do get uncomfortable and the table is very small. I may come back for take out but not eating in as it's not very comfortable to relax and eat.

A very decent lunch option if you feeling fancy and want to treat yourself to something different. Seasoning is spot on and thankfully they haven't adopted the American portion size which give room to try a variety of options in one sitting.

Amazing drinks, but hainan chicken did not live up to my expectations. The pieces of chicken were abnormally big... I would go back for their coffee though
