No comment

I loved the lobah which reminds me very much of the Fujian five-spice pork rolls. Anchovies seemed to be a big part of the Malaysian cuisine; 2 of the dishes we ordered had anchovies and after a while they were indistinguishable. The Hainan chicken was on point and so was the spinach. I don't love the ambiance of this place which is why I give only 3 stars. The tables were small and the stools were super uncomfortable. There was no place to hang coats and not much room to wait for next open table. The place is popular obviously but if I were to come back (just for the lobah) I would only come in the summer.
The iced white coffee is so addicting! It's a small place and hard to overlook when searching for it, but once you've been there once, you'll be going again and again.

Small, simple, and unassuming restaurant gives way to a fresh and creative little space. The chef is onto something, dishing out traditional Malaysian breakfast, snacks, and mains. Drink variety is better than I've seen and the much talked about nasi Lemak isn't even close to overrated.

I've done take out from Kopitiam so many times and I am constantly amazed by how solidly delicious their food is. All the things I've tried are excellent: pulut panggang, pulut inti, pan mee, and of course their bek kopi. Comfort food on the go one day I hope to actually eat in and enjoy the food in its natural restaurant environment!
No comment
No comment

Love the concept of all their food being made fresh on the spot upon each order. Apparently this gold mine has been in the neighborhood for about two years now and I'm just making my first visit now!  A bit pricey for the amount of food, but it's not bad quality. I've mainly ordered their sweets so far. I did try their nasi lamak, but a bit disappointed that it was for $8 and there was no curry chicken! Maybe I was spoiled by other Malay places, but there was no curry in this nasi lamak. There was a whole egg tho . But I'll go elsewhere for it. I def recommend their lychee mochi! $5.44(after tax)! Wish they could've given more pieces. Think there was no more than 8 pieces in the box! T°T saddens me cause it's quite delish but so expensive. Guess it'll have to be saved for major craving days for the safety of my wallet

I have no doubt that the food is great but packaging needs A LOT of work. I haven't arrived home yet but the drinks are leaking from its baggies (no cups which is eco friendly but you need a better way to hold those bags up...) and the brown bag holding everything broke through bc oil was leaking from another item inside so everything eventually fell out. The packaging was horrible execution all around.

As a Malaysian native, the iconic Nasi Lemak was nothing like what it was supposed to be. The sambal was not sambal, and the Oh Chien was super starchy and gooey - should've used less tapioca starch. One outstanding dish was the Lobak which was probably one of the best I've had. However all in all, it was a less than satisfying visit unfortunately.

This place is super cute. It's very trendy and has a super hip vibe. I recommend the duck tongue. It was grilled perfectly with the right amount of spice. My biggest regret is that I forgot to take a picture before I devoured it. The white coffee is also delicious! I highly recommend this place!

This was my first time having Malaysian food! I was really impressed by the prices/portions. We ordered nasi lemak, pulut panggang, bandung, and butter toast. We preferred the nasi lemak to the pulut panggang, probably because of the textural contrast of the fried anchovy. Those two dishes were a little salty to my taste, but that may just be the Malaysian food style. We were quite impressed by the butter toast: it tastes very coconutty (pandan?) and buttery, the toast is well crisped, and went well with the bandung. I would recommend ordering the bandung less sweet - 75% was perfect for my partner, a tad too sweet still for me. I will definitely be back!

The first time I went to Kopitiam (back at their old location), I ordered a teh tarik and was really disappointed by the tea that left an acrid taste in my mouth. Recently, I've returned to check out their new location and am happy to report various improvements, the first being the space. Kopitiam has lost its literal hole-in-the-wall charm that made it so appealing to me in the first place but the expanded seating and cleanliness of the new store are two things I can get behind. Another improvement is the menu availability-- no longer will I have to wait for specific days of the week to order certain dishes. The quality of the food doesn't seem to have changed, but I did notice the packaging of their iced teh tarik is now in a cute little plastic pouch, much like what you would find throughout most of Southeast Asia. It's less acrid and smoother, but I think the recipe can be improved upon.

This cafe is a small hole in a wall place in chitown. I ordered the beef renang which was the special dish of the day. The beef renang sauce was flavorfull, authentic and perfectly spicy for an Asian person. The white coffee was absolutely amazing! The coconut rice desert and white coffee are a great combination together! This place usually gets filled very quickly. We were lucky to find good seats inside the cafe.

I had the skate special and it was perfectly cooked. I loved everything about it but the only reason it's not a 5 is that the sauce was too salty for me; however, if I had it with rice or noodles it would have worked well. I would definitely go back for more.
No comment

The Malaysian food here is very authentic. It's very spicy. I ordered coffee nesi lamak and the sticky rice with dried shrimp. It's good. The only suggestion is to call in to place your order because it is very small inside.

Really good "pulled coffee". The one I had was pretty sweet, so if you like sweet coffee, you will love this. I'm sure they have less sweet versions. Really sweet girl behind counter. Small place though. Will def go back to try the food

5-star review for one of my favorite places in New York which I am gonna miss a lot in the future! Very authentic Malaysian food! Cute and welcoming place to go in the winter! Check their white coffee and mochi for sure!
Great and well priced! Got the cold sesame noodles along with the vegetarian drumstick and was quite pleased

I really want to like this place. Like the vibe a lot. I usually love Asian fusion. I am super open minded about that and have embraced restaurants this type and I am one of those Williamsburg foodie hipster myself that people condemn for being a gullible market for overpriced artisanal things - as I don't mind paying more for a comfortable experience. The problem is that the dishes they make, just didn't click. Something is missing. I get it that they try to be modern, but they lost that depth of umami-ness you usually find in Asian dishes. (Whether it's authentic or fusion). I love their cleanness  and really good bathroom tho, I usually hate going to Chinatown's restaurants bathroom usually - if that's any consolation.

Was so excited about the reopening of Kopitiam but was somewhat disappointed. On the third day after their grand reopening, we went for lunch and was told many of their items were sold out. No problem. We ordered the Nasi Lemak, muah chee and white coffees (all excellent as usual, hence the three stars) and their oyster omelette. The omelette was well seasoned, but after digging through the entire dish, we found not one shred of oyster. Not one piece. We asked our server about it and she told us she would ask the kitchen. After waiting for a long time with no response, we left. $10 for a bowl of eggs is not okay. If you are out of ingredients, just let us know. We are reasonable people, really. But serving a dish without the main ingredient and then not responding to a customer's question about it, that's not ok.
No comment

Stopped in for lunch on a rainy Sunday and it was totally worth it! The flavors of every dish were incredible, simply described as "complex". The curry puff, chilled spicy sesame noodles and criss cross shrooms were incredible. Also had the pan mee, which was good for cold, rainy day. Looking forward to coming back and trying the Nasi Lemak and some coffee. The folks were there are really friendly.

The staff is so friendly! Both Gracelyn and Winnie were very helpful in answering all of the (many) questions I had. The ice coffee made by Gracelyn definitely hit the spot for me. Cold, strong and not too sweet! The toast was also delightful and throughly enjoyed. Can't wait to come back here to try more items on the menu
No comment
No comment

First, this was my first time ever having Singaporean food so I don't have anything to compare it to. With that said, the food was amazing. Delivery was fast. I will surely order from this again. I had the Pan Mee and Pandan Chicken.
Loved it! Really unique take on Malaysia street food. Enjoyed the deserts and the pandan chicken. Cheeky set up inside, really cute.
After spending sometime working in Malaysia, I needed a Kl fix and this place did not disappoint.
No comment

Came across this on insider's food video and had to come and try it out with my friend. We got here around late afternoon and it was already packed, but we got seats. We ordered the Nasi Lemak and Palut Tai Tai and the Muah Chee. They didn't have the Nasi Lemak anymore so we couldn't try it. Palut Tai Tai we got it with the Kaya jam and i thought the taste put together was incredible and the rice was still hot too which made it taste really good. For the Muah Chee it was mochi with peanut, sesame and sugar it was really good because the mochi was still hot when we got it and it sort of just melted in our mouths. Overall the food tasted really good and the service was really good.
butter toast and coffee soooooo good. great service. Vegan chicken drumsticks to die for. I would go back just for the butter toast again

I love the concept of Malaysian and Singapore coffee house treats in NYC! The place is small, but SO worth the wait in line. Kaya toast was good, the teh tarik was AMAZING, the nasi lemak was nice and spicy (though I wish it had a larger piece of fish or even a chicken drumstick, to make it just a little more substantial). Service was friendly and you get to watch your food be prepared to order. They even had Kuih Lapis that day, and oh man, it was such a treat!!

Finally I visited this place. Came on Presidents' Day and it was pretty empty. It is a cafe so you order at the counter. Very cozy space and a place where I would get coffee. The kopi Tarik was very tasty similar to a viet coffee but not as strong. We ordered the nasi lemak which was ok. For the price I was thinking it would be a larger meal and other garnishes. The oh chien was very good. You can taste the oyster and omelette was a little under which I like. They spicy stir fried duck tongue was delicious. I haven't had duck tongue in over ten years so having this made my day. The sauce lured well. I would come back and try the other snacks and dishes.

WOOO Malaysian food! No wait, like the real deal. I have never had Malaysian snacks before but thankfully Kopitiam has made their apperarance in NYC! I absolutely love their white coffee, I never even knew such a thing exist but watching how it was made was really intriguing. I didn't get a chance to check out their snacks but I will definitely be back as everything is SUPER wallet friendly- not to mention how amazing their staff is!

Some of the best food I've had! I live in DC which is known for phenomenal food and this really made me acknowledge that NYC restaurants are up there. The hospitality was also to die for. The place was cozy, welcoming and authentic. 11/10 would recommend.
No comment
No comment

This place is delicious!  The Milo French Toast is decadent.  But all the toasts look amazing.  We also had the one with peanuts on top--which was also great.  If you like anchovies, go for the Nasi Lemak.  That is a very popular dish there.  But every dish on all the tables looks delicious.  I want to keep going back so I can try them all!  The coffees are good--the white coffee just seems a bit milder.

Very fast service and good food. The only reason it's 2 stars less than it deserves was because of the change of the food container from rectangular to a smaller circle container. Also I noticed that the portion of the foods doesn't seem to be portioned correctly each time. Sometimes there are less of the dried fish than usual.
Prawn Noodles is very bland. The soup is watery. Ask for chilli sauce, they don't have.
No comment
No comment

Yay cheap eats! This place is a low-key, no-frills, place to grab a quick bite. There are only four seats so you have to get lucky to sit down. The mua chee is just like the mua chee you'd get in a Singaporean hawker center. It's deliciously chewy and covered in sugary peanutty goodness. The nasi lemak is a yummy late night snack. The rice is coconutty and the ikan billies with peanuts are flavorful. I definitely want to come back to try the other menu items!

Haven't developed a habit of taking pictures yet. The Malaysian signature dish(coconut rice with dried fish) is always a safe choice for first timers. White coffee and veggie fried chicken are above average too.

Yasss...finally a place where I can get my nasi lemak and Kaya fix! This hole in the wall place (there are literally 5 seats in the entire cafe) is pretty easy to miss as it's rather indescript. Menu choice is small but they have my favorites like nasi lemak, kueh, teh tarik and milo so you can't really go wrong. Ordered the nasi lemak which comes with cucumber, sambal and an egg for $5.50. Did I mention the sambal is some of the best I have had in the city? Finished off with a $3 Kaya toast, this is a home away from home place at a low price point. Will definitely visit this place many more times!

I like the coffee back then before they moved.  Here I'm in the new location with a expanded menu with a lot of authentic Malaysia food.  My girlfriend and a lot of my friends are Malaysian,  and I definitely expenience a lot of different restaurant.  What I can say the food is very goodand authentic.  Place is clean and cozy  Price is reasonable in New York City.  Place is crowded and don't expect to stay to eat too long.  This is more like a self serve sencerio.  Will come back again.
No comment
Ordered because I heard they have a few vegan items on their menu, and I ended up getting two vegan desserts. They were so fresh, not too sweet, and really delicious. Would definitely go back.
No comment
My mother and I always get the handcut noodle soup with the anchovies and its just as good each time. Gets pretty busy sometimes, but they have delivery if you don't want to fight for seats.
No comment
No comment

I've never had real Malaysian food before Kopitiam came along on Canal street. Everything was so amazing, delicious and new, I loved it. Then they closed. But now they are back with a bigger space and bigger menu! The Nasi Lemak is fantastic. The breakfast toasts are good and the deserts are also great. Looking forward to trying the rest of the menu!
No comment
We had kaya toast and coffee Tariq for breakfast. We liked it. The service is very good. Bathrooms are very clean. Will come back!
I am trying to support all the local restaurants so I place an order from Kopitiam. Unfortunately the food was ok. But I still appreciate them for being open for us. Thank you

I ordered a tea and some sweet through the yelp website, but apparently, it is not connected to the restaurant. But the people there were very nice, they did my order right away!!! The tea and the cake were excellent!!!! Thanks again!!!
This place is small and cute. We got the purple sticky rice to go. It is sweet sticky rice with fried coconuts on the top. The rice texture is great. The rice is not too sweet. 86 is a nice dish.
No comment

Had rice w enchovies, eggs, white coffee and pan dan noodle. They were good. Too much food for one. Couldn't finish. Lots of young asian people. Trendy clean cool decor. Came on sat morning. Place got filled up pretty quickly as soon as they are open. Nice spot to come alone for a bite and as well as group. Staff are very nice and friendly. You order at the counter and they will bring food for you. One dish is pretty filling for one person. I would just get one dish per person. Young asian group seating next to me was talking about how much they love living in NY. Couldn't agree more. If you are single, seems like a good place to meet people. I would come back again.

How can this place have an average of 4 stars?! This place is amazing all-around from the food to the staff. I can't say enough good things. I've enjoyed every meal here. The food is just so damn tasty. The Kaya Butter Toast is a must as well as the Nasi Lemak.
No comment

The white coffee is a must try! Delicious food and a great enjoyable ambiance. Food felt like it was cooked from a warm home meal maximizing the flavors. The staff and owners were very friendly. Must revisit! The food hit the spot right away and made me order more. Definitely worth a revisit. The place is a cafe/restaurant like. Great place to chill and hang out for a meet up or date.
No comment
No comment

Great spot for some traditional Malay cuisine!  They have a simple menu that covers all the things one can enjoy. Try a little bit of everything. It's worth the experience to get all these flavors. Enjoy!

I was very impressed with the food and drink coming out of this tiny Malaysian restaurant in Chinatown. With only a few seats to sit, our group decided to do takeout and bring our food to a nearby park. Service was friendly, fast and very efficient. Prices were excellent - so affordable! My Malaysian iced coffee with condensed milk was delicious and refreshing and not at all too sweet, in my opinion! I ordered the nasi lemak for my meal and it was a large portion of rice served with sambal, anchovies, peanuts, cucumbers and more. It's a distinct, unusual flavor for those who have never tried it before, but having eaten this dish many times around the world I do believe that at this restaurant was one of the best!

Little walk-in shop in Chinatown boosting big, bold flavors! You can smell the food aromas of the shop coming up the street, which stopped several people in their tracks with glee. While seating is limited inside the shop, there is a bench outside as well so you don't have to do cash & carry with your food. (And the people watching at Dimes restaurant next door is quite entertaining as you wait/eat on the bench.) I got the Pulut Panggang and Soft Boiled eggs and mixed them together- so good! Eggs were perfectly runny and the yolk broke over the coconut rice with shrimp paste filling in the most satisfying way. The spicy sauce that comes with the Pulut Panggang is flavorful with just right amount of heat.
No comment

I am going to give this place a solid 2 stars. Not because the service wasn't good, but the food just didn't taste that good. Everything tasted spoiled. I might give this place another chance since I pass it almost everyday due to its close proximity to my job but we'll see. Hopefully I can update my review to a higher number of stars on my next visit.
No comment
No comment

My wife and I just came back from a month long vacation in Malaysia and had a craving for some Pan mee. Wasn't sure we would find some  that tasted as good in NYC but this place gave me the pan mee fix I needed . Although the price for a bowl is $11 which comes out to rm44 at least it didn't disappoint. Made with real love and experience of this Malaysian noodle soup. I will be back for some Pan mee when the craving hits me.

This is a hidden gem in NYC! Thanks for serving authentic Malaysian dishes and drinks that are so true to the taste of home. We enjoyed the Nasi Lemak, Kopi Tarik, Pulut Panggang and Muah Chee! It was our first time and definitely not our last! we'll be back soon! highly recommended!
No comment

I've had mixed experiences with Malaysian food in the past. From inedible sardine soup (won't mention where), to mind blowing Roti Jala at Kedai Makan in Seattle. Regardless I went in with high expectations and boy were they met. The Nasi Lemak came out quickly and was accompanied by an excellent sambal sauce that complimented the crispy anchovies and perfectly cooked rice.  The cold sesame noodles were tasty and reminded me of wontons in chili oil found at many Szechuan restaurants throughout NYC, but would have been better on a warmer day. The pan mee soup was good but lacked a defining edge after all the anchovy in the Nasi Lemak. Regardless, it was tasty and the homemade noodles were a great bite. The cross cross shrooms had a depth of flavor that's origin is really beyond me. Coconut, cumin and chili combine with something else wonderful to make for a firefly climax of the meal. Served along side a tight packed bowl of coconut rice to cool it down, delish. A very satisfying meal that only looses a star due to being spoiled by Kedai Makan. It's not you, it's me, I swear.

Came here by myself and ordered the iced white coffee, kaya toast, and the nasi lemak. They were all good. I'm usually a black coffee drinker (no sugar or milk) but decided to try the white coffee since it's so popular. It was pretty good. Tasted a bit like coffee with hint of milk tea.  Note that it is not as strong as black coffee. It was also not too sweet which I liked. The kaya toast was sweet and good. The anchovy rice (nasi lemak) was flavorful. They have a side of spicy sauce which you can mix into the rice yourself. That sauce was pretty flavorful, and quite spicy and salty. I don't eat anchovies often and don't really like or hate them, but first several bites tasted pretty good. After a while, it starts getting salty. I had to alternate between eating the sweet toast and the salty rice to be able to finish everything I ordered.  I intended on coming here for snacks, but ended up filling myself with a meal.
Coffee and sweets were nice. Had to wait a while for the Pan Mee, but really enjoyed it. It was something different, but homey and comforting.

If you don't like piles of anchovies atop your food, make sure when ordering that there won't be any on your chosen dish. I thought one of the two things I ordered wouldn't come with anchovies - should have paid closer attention.
Pan mee noodle is so lit! My girl and I got most of the menu. The duck tongue is also a must order!

I've been wanting to try this place for a while. Was finally in Chinatown today and went for it. Had the muah chee (warm mochi with crushed peanuts, sugar, sesame seeds), pulut panggang, and cold sesame noodles with soft boiled egg. Everything was fairly priced, around $5-$5.50, except for the iced black tea with condensed milk, which was a whooping $4.50 and also fairly small (12 oz). The sesame noodles weren't as good as they looked. The noodles were a bit hard and the egg didn't add anything to the dish. The pulut panggang was very nice. The muah chee was super tasty but too sweet. I would come back and try the other items.
No comment

I LOVE THIS TINY GEM OF A PLACE! Next door to the ever crowded trendy dimes, this modest eatery serves authentic and super tasty Malaysian food, drinks, and sweets. Service is super friendly and patient! I got the iced teh Tarik, oyster omelette special that comes with sweet chili sauce and sambal, and a small piece of these yucca/coconut cakes they had on display. I'm Taiwanese and I love my oyster omelettes to no end but this Malay version blew me away and dare I admit this - I think it's even better. The sauces it came with were PERFECT and packed quite a bit of heat, but the iced teh tarik was just what I needed for that. I was quite full after the omelette because it is a decent portion so I did not have room for the pulut inti that I originally wanted, but the staff recommended the yucca cake and I was not disappointed! It was a bit chilled, tasted not too sweet, and had a really fragrant coconut taste to it. Everything I got was amazing and I'm sure everything else on the menu is too. The only thing I wish they had was more space and better ventilation because the smoke from cooking really does get everywhere and it did bother my eyes and all my clothes and hair still smell like smoke. My best friend is Malaysian and I adore her moms cooking and this place sent me right back to my childhood - I couldn't stop raving to my friend about it during and after my whole transcending experience at this lil hole in the wall. Definitely can and will be coming back to try as many things as possible!!!

I'm in awe. The food here is incredible and the atmosphere is lighthearted and casual. Anytime someone is visiting me, I take them here to get a wide array of different flavors, it's truly for everyone. Everything on the menu is great, lots of gluten free and dairy free options as well. I'd give an extra special shoutout to the pandan chicken!
Such a unique cafe place but the seating is so confusing...Maybe change from a person assigning seats to just people grab seats, I think we all know how it works....
No comment
No comment

Oh yeah!! Can't believe how cheap this place is! For $20.50 we had two nasi lemak's, pulut panggang and otak otak. Absolutely amazing! This is a hole in the wall, with nowhere to sit really, just 5 stools to grab a seat if you're lucky and a wooden bench outside. Totally worth it though for the authentic food! Check out my pics!!

I was excited to check out Kopitiam, it was a compact little shop but they sold many interesting items. I ordered a iced milk tea it was delicious! The main reason I went there was to get the coconut jam and the sambal chili, I have yet to try them but I ended with more items than that. I also had the otak-otak - I bought 3 of them and tried one immediately it was aromatic wrapped in the banana leave and it was quite a large one but very very spicy. They did not spare the use of fresh chili peppers that I could tell you. My nose was running so I told my husband he probably should give it a miss. I liked the spicy aspect but flavor wise I thought it was a lightly lacking in some of the flavors and the texture was not quite what I expected from the ones I had in Singapore. I liked the nasi lemak it was well executed flavorful coconut rice and spicy anchovies/peanuts, the sambal was good. I just had the kueh lapis, the layered cake it was not too bad not as soft as expected but still tasty. I thought overall everything was good but a bit pricy. The sliver of kueh half an inch thick by 3 inches long was $1.90.

Amazing!!! So authentic. Added to my New York visit. Service was unreal too. We asked the staff to choose dishes for us and we had a blast. Deserts were great too. Owner was very hands on and a sweetheart!! Loved this place.

I haven't been to the new location- so this review is for the old location. I love the unusual menu items, and the Malaysian tea is poured so beautifully. It's like an art. I crave the tea and can't wait to go back.

Very nice, promising, Malaysian eatery.  Excellent customer service.  Nice place for a get together with small groups of friends.   I've been here many times since opening.  Lack a little consistency when it comes to the traditional Tarik tea. Sometimes it is too water down sometimes too bitter.  Pandan and kaya toast are delicious.  Fried finger foods are great but need consistency when it comes to level of saltiness. Lately, very salty. I think, once they get consistency part right, definitely would be a five star eatery.
No comment

Kopitiam delivers a unique representation of Southeast Asian cuisine with an assortment of quick and small bites in the heart of Ctown. Although the appearance of store front may look shady or even trashy (particularly at night), the place is legit and truly a hole in the wall. Let's just say, you'll never know what treasures lie within if you do not have the courage to step inside.
The food are delicious.  They make everything fresh.  If I live nearby, I will order from them all the time.
No comment
No comment
Dat white coffee tho. They take credit cards, so if you're in the hood stop by. You have NO EXCUSE NOT TO MUHAHAA

Great owners with the desire to maintain their cultural Malaysian roots. Enjoyed speaking to them and really appreciate the authenticity to their food. Def a type of street food that is different and you won't find anywhere else.

Okay, totally hooked on their nasi lemak and spicy rice noodle. My son, on their pan mei. My daughter, their desserts. Had their white coffee today and loved it. Didn't get it the drinks in their cool baggies today. Working my way through their menu. Cheery service and the utmost patience with clueless customers like me.
No comment
The place is very tiny. We only had the muah che but it was delicious warm and the topping was sweet and nutty. I would come back and try the savory food.
This place has tasty Malaysian food and sweets with authentic flavors.  We had the sweet sticky, nasi lemak and teh tarik. Space is limited so we did not stay here for long. It's good for takeout.
I really liked everything I had here. We had Nasi Lemak, fish ball soup with noodle, kaya toast, white coffee, and fresh soy milk. Everything was rly good. Food was tasty and service was great!

Popped in for a bite this afternoon and was not disappointed - new Kopitiam was a pleasant surprised. Loved the space - light and welcoming and easy to find a good seat. Service was fast - food and servers and the tables were quickly cleaned and taken care of. We ordered Nasi Lemak, Pandan chicken, fishcake soup and coffee and everything was tasty, which chicken being simply amazing. Personally, I wish Nasi came with a protein besides anchovies but won't take a star away for that and will be back again so keep up the good work!
Wow - food here is amazing! Everything we tried was authentic Malaysian and delicious. Highly recommend this. Try everything!

Well I guess it's a lot to expect to get really authentic Malaysian food. This seems so impossible outside of Penang. For sure, the key ingredients are not easily obtainable. In any event, this place might be worth stopping by if they begin to offer up soups such as Asam Laksa, Curry Mee and/or Hokkien Mee.
No comment
This traditional Malaysian coffee house is very good. Food and drinks are taste good, and service is good too. But the place very small and only have four seats.

I'm from Singapore and have not been back for a year and won't be back for another half a year, so I was pretty glad to have found this place on Yelp. I ordered iced milo, Kaya toast and oyster omelet, and they were (obviously) not up to the standards of Singapore and Malaysia. The oyster omelet was bad, the milo was a little diluted and the toast was okay. If I were at Singapore, I would've rated this place one star, but since it reminded me of home, and since it also serves as a way to introduce people to Singaporean and Malaysian food, I rate this place three stars. Overall, it's quite reasonably priced, tastes average, but if you've never tried Malaysian food, it's a good enough introduction to it. I'll still recommend this place, but I won't go out of my way for it.

Love this hidden Malaysian cafe! Authentic Malaysian signature dishes and pastries, remind me of childhood memories in Malaysia. Must try their bak kut teh (herbal pork bone soup), Nasi Lemak (dried anchovies coconut rice), shredded coconut in green wrap (dessert!), and their white coffee (hot or cold). Price is very reasonable considered everything is made to order. If you are looking for real malaysian dishes, this is the place to go!
WARNING: The food here is usually good but sometimes when you order drinks to go they skimp on them. I ordered an Iced Teh Tarik and it tasted like straight water.

I thought nasi lemak wasn't my thing after trying it from other restaurants but clearly those other places didn't know how to make it right. Kopitiam has made me a huge fan of the dish. Their kaya toast was so sweet and buttery and delicious. Those 2 are must haves if you visit :)
No comment

Literally perfect. Came here and immediately sated my kaya toast and half boiled egg cravings from Singapore (where I first imprinted to those dishes)... aaand then those cravings returned with a vengeance like five minutes later so now I'm going to be back all the time. The iced bek-kopi coffee and curry puff are insane too.

I have been dying to try it out for the longest but never got a chance to since it's so out of my way. But today was the day, I had to! I order the Kuih Dadar and Penang White Coffee to stay and the Nasi Lemak and Pulut Panggang to go...might as well to taste it at home. Even though I stopped drinking coffee I made the exception to try and and it was absolutely goodddddddd. I was very impressed by the finely grated coconut in palm sugar of the Kuih Dadar...yummmmm! Later on in the day I finally tried the Nasi Lemak and the Pulut Panggang...I was able to taste the individual ingredients ssssssssssooooooo good, it brought me back home to Indonesia, very similar taste and culture. I was very satisfied and the staff was so friendly, they made me feel very welcome. See you definitely soon guys! It was worth the time and the walk
Excellent Malaysian coffee (my first time trying!) and food, really enjoyed coming here! The coffee was unlike any I've ever tried - definitely recommend it.

Cute little shop for desserts or a quick bite. I liked the pandan cake, it wasn't too sweet. The white coffee was more like a latte without the foam, it was ok as I prefer my coffee a tad stronger and without sweetener but if u use sugar then you'll prob like it. I also had the nesi lamak which was ok, it's similar to the anchovies u can get at Korean supermarkets as bonbon/ apps. I usually eat this over rice as a meal so it wasn't new for me. Otherwise I'd come back for the desserts!

I got the coconut rice and it tastes so good with the mini anchovy thing. I tried to pay in cash but the guy at the counter was like "the boss isn't here and I don't wanna touch it" so that was unexpected. Also he didn't even finish wrapping my take out order. Just gave me a plastic bag for me to do it. What's going on here?

Great meal. Excellent flavors. Charming hospitality. Arrived at 6pm on a Thurs and practically had the place to ourselves. Love the casual and quick service and for $40 (2 people) we ate like champs. Will have to return for the weekend specials. The pandan chicken and lobak were awesome! Go!

Tried the pulut panggang the other time, wasn't a big fan as it was a bit hard to eat outside and quite salty, but their nasik lemak is fire. Spicy and salty anchovies in sambal on a bed of velvety smooth coconut rice and fresh cucumber slices and creamy hardboiled eggs, pretty damn great. Thumbs up! Gotta try the kaya toast, eggs and kopi next time.
No comment

4.5 stars (round up because of the service) the only reason I'm knocking off 1/2 a star is because when we arrived they had sold out of 3/5 menu items that we wanted to order (the pork appetiser, the pork noodles and the sticky rice roll). But the service was absolutely excellent and the food that we had was delicious and tasted authentic. Servings are small compared to many places in New York. The Nasi lemak was fragrant and pungent, and the pandan chicken was flavoursome and unique- I've never had anything quite like it before.

I really likes this cute little place but it was busy. We waited awhile for our order to be ready. But the wait was worth it. I especially enjoyed the nasi lemak. The sambal was really really good in my book. I should have orders the sambal in a jar to take home. Definitely next time when I'm in New York again.
No comment

I was underwhelmed by the food here, especially after all the hype. Came early on a Thursday night (~6:30) and didn't have a problem getting a seat. Ordered the pan mee and cross cut mushrooms. Mushrooms were good but nothing special (coconut rice it comes with was the best part.) The Pan Mee was very bland but the hand pulled noodles had a good texture. Their weekend menu looked more promising than the weekday. Would have also loved for Roti Canai to be on the menu.

I don't know anything at all about Malaysian food so I really can't comment authoritatively on the food, but just have to praise the young men who work here for their kindness and customer service.  They carried my massive stroller up and down the stairs in the rain without me even asking and let me occupy a 4-top table alone with my infant.  Very welcoming atmosphere.  I loved the white coffee too!
Delicious food, lovely owner, and a cozy, all-day cafe! Everything we had was delicious, although the toast and eggs weren't worth the price. I've been back several times, and it is always a treat!
No comment
Perfect litte gem! Please stay forever! Everything here is delicious, every single thing. My favorite is the Kaya butter toast and white coffee.
No comment
No comment

One of the only places in the US to get authentic Singaporean cafe-style food! Try the kaya toast, it's incredible. The rest of the menu looked great too, but I didn't get to try it. I met one of the owners while I was eating there, and she couldn't have been nicer or more generous. I highly, highly recommend this place for a unique cafe experience in NYC.
No comment

Love it!!!! Never love Malaysian food that much. The store is new, so it's very clean. The lady who work in the front is also lovelyI came here everyday start with the white coffee or the hand pulled tea. Everyday they will have different savory everyday, must try it!! The Friday chilled spicy sesame noodle is a must have, it's my fav.

I came here for a light meal with my friends when I was in the area since we wanted to try out some authentic malaysian cuisine. The interior is pretty small and there's only a few seats at window but it did seem very legit. I got a nasi lemak which is kind of like the default malay dish and really liked the anchovies paired with the peanuts. I would wanna come back and try the other items on the menu!!
No comment

This place is great to stop by. The food and beverages are amazing. Had the white coffee and the rose tea. Both are to die for. Sweet and savory are both divine. Kaya butter toast are a must. Can't wait to try everything else. Staff is really helpful and friendly. All items are very reasonably priced.

This modest coffee shop and eatery delivers on some very good Malaysian food, redolent with the spices of the country and complex with the five flavors in good Asian cuisine. The Nasi Lemak was a delight, a mound of fragrant rice that had good coconut flavor. The saltiness of the anchovies was offset by the sweetness if the sauce. With a few slices of cucumber as garnish, it was a solid winner. The Pulut Panggang , a log of glutinous rice with a inner core of minced lemongrass flavored shrimp thread, was beautifully presented wrapped in a striped green leaf. The garnish of cucumbers on the side provided a contrasting crunch and the sambal sauce on it added seasoning.The staples holding the ends was a modern touch perhaps necessitated by a need to seal with speed. Yes, string would have been more apropos, but at $5.50 an entree, one can't expect Master Chef presentations. The log was quite tasty, albeit a tad sweet when it came to the sambal sauce. Neither dish was overly spicy, perhaps that and the  extra sugar a slight concession to the Americanized palate. Portions were good for one, if you are a hearty eater, order two meals or more. The place is clean but small, with two small counters and if I remember, four chairs. Chubby and burly folk, take your order to go, unless you want to cosy up to some stranger. Service here is on the slower side. This isn't fast food but food prepared with love. Be patient. The staff are sweet and the food is worth it. Don't bother trying to figure out the menu via the wall poster unless you are Malaysian and know the cuisine. If you see a photo that makes your stomach say gimme, just ask the amiable staff.
The coffee was really good. The nasi lemak was also tasty but I would not go out of my way to come here.

Really good authentic Malaysian food! Everything's really affordable AND they accept credit card (no minimum) now. Get the sesame noodles, the nasi lemak (anchovies and coconut rice), the kaya toast (pandan coconut jam), and the teh tarik.
This is a super fantastic Malaysia restaurant! I totally mesmerized by the flavor. Amazing!
Mother effing Pan Dam Jam is my jam!!!! That and the condensed milk coffee, yum!

Specially travelled all the way here to satisfy my hometown craving. Ordered ondeh ondeh, nasi lemak, ban mee and otak. The ondeh ondeh skin is way too thick while there is barely any gula melaka inside. The nasi lemak is pathetic, barely any coconut aroma. Ban mee is okay but lacks authenticity. The noodle is much thicker than it should be. Otak has way too much lemongrass which really shouldn't be so in reality; the taste is totally off! In short, this place is overhyped. Definitely not the place to be if you are looking for authentic malaysia/singapore food.

Kopitiam is a tiny Malaysian eatery. Everything has been consistent there. They offer excellent services and authentic tastes. There are a few stools if you choose to eat there. However, just a friendly reminder that the smoke from the kitchen can irritate your eyes when the place gets busy.

Meh...was expecting so much more. The food was sort of okay, but nothing spectacular. The Pandan Chicken was atrocious since it was raw. The anchovies dish (Nasi Lemak) was good, so was the Kaya Butter Toast. The lobak was average as well. The drinks were not great either (I had the MJ and Sugarcane Juice)-not their fault on them since they are pre-packaged but all in all a bit of a let down.

It was my first time here and got the Malaysian white coffee. This was delicious! The staff here is really friendly and courteous. A great find in NYC. I also saw someone ordered a Nasi Lemak and it looked amazing.

Wonderful little place at the corner of Canal and Orchard. While I didn't have the coffee the "Nasi Lemak" was excellent, a a rice bowl  including Coconut Rice with Egg, Cucumber & Anchovy" It comes with a little container of Sambal Sauce (Sambal is a hot sauce typically made from a mixture of variety of chili peppers with secondary ingredients such as shrimp paste, fish sauce, garlic, ginger, shallot, scallion, palm sugar, lime juice, and rice vinegar or other vinegars). That said you might want to taste the sambal sauce in advance, it's a killer!

Nestled in Chinatown near Ludlow and next to trendy Dimes, this small (sometimes shoulder-to-shoulder when busy) Malaysian cafe serves delicious tastes for the seeker of sweet and satisfying, bitter and challenging, as well as spicy and sumptuous treats. The portions may be small but the plates are intense and flavorful. Try the beehive cake for a melt-in-your-mouth sweet and a traditional Malay coffee for the most unique cup of joe you've had in the city. I recommend the spicy cold noodles for the experience of what I can only describe as both refreshing and blazing at the same time. Oh, and the coconut sweet rice cakes are blue - just devour and grace your tastebuds with its color!

Definitely a hole-in-the-wall establishment but it's offering is tasty and authentic. Limited menu items allows them to focus on the quality of its offerings. There are a few seats with limited space for in-dining. A short distance walk from East Broadway station makes it easily accessible.

We ordered Nasi Lemak, stingray and Oh chien (oyster omelette. )  Food was not up to standard. Stingray was a ripoff: expensive, filled with cilantro to cover up the inadequacy of stingray.  Oh chien was...where were the oysters?  The best was probably the Nasi Lemak because of the cucumber and hardboiled eggs.  If you're feeling "homesick " save yourself a trip.

Kopitiam is an unassuming tiny coffee shop with seating for 4 between Chinatown and LES. If you're wondering what a Malaysian breakfast is like swing by in the morning for a sweet snack and an order of their unique white coffee. They also serve tea. You can also go there for some lunch as there are plenty of savory items on the menu as well. They are all good. Everything on the menu is dedicatedly made by the owner/ chef of the shop who learned how to cook from her parents. Take your order to go & dine al fresco at the nearby park.
No comment

I love this place. Decent food with great service. It is a place where you wouldn't stay too long because the space is very small. My only complaint is the cleanliness of this place. I understand it is in Chinatown and the place is old but it can still be cleaned up a little.
Great food and amazing catering service. Definitely a good place to go for a satisfactory meal. Very well priced and well craft dishes. Would recommend this restaurant.

Small enough that you might end up sharing a communal table just to get a seat, but the food is so delicious and the place is so fun that you won't care. Also, they are roughly two doors down from a great basement-level bookstore so you can browse while waiting for friends to show up.

hands down the best malaysian spot in the city. ive been to malaysia, and my wife is malaysian as well, and we both love the authenticity of the dishes. the criss cross shroom are so good i want to kidnap the chef who makes it. and i think they sprinkled crack in the white coffee. the decor is warm and friendly; thought was put into everything from the exposed beams in the ceiling, to what kind of handsoap is used in the bathrooms. the staff is fun, friendly, and energetic. if you want to avoid a packed house, hit it up during the week. and do try Kai's desserts; proceeds go to paying for his culinary education!

Kopitiam...I'm sad to say it has lose its charm. I remember a year ago when I first discovered it, it was such a nice spot!! But what happened now..the cleanliness dropped significantly, wall decoration is full of dust, staff attitude is just..meh. I'm not sure why. Today I went for the kaya toast, the toast was burnt until it is black and they still passed it to me. I discovered it and quickly asked for a new order. They remade it for me, gave it to me without feeling sorry, all they wanted is to close the store. No thank you, not a word of sorry. Feel so sad to say I will never come back again even though I love Malaysian food.
No comment

The food is amazing. I am so happy Kopitiam has a great space to sit and eat now. It's really cute and trendy inside their new location. The food is affordable and authentic. They also serve drinks that I have never even heard of or tried! It is absolutely refreshing to see new drinks that aren't basic. Everything is so delicious from drinks, desserts to main meals. There is always a line out the door and that's when you know it's a good place!!!
Blue sticky rice was perfectly executed, and very tasty.  Staff is pleasant and the price point is right.  This is definitely a treat for this city and I do hope it lasts!

overrated. Soft boiled egg (2 to an order) almost 4 bucks? Anchovies were crispy and salty, the nuts added a nice kick but otherwise the breakfast was heavy on the rice esp for $8. $12 is not a good price for what they offered. Attitude is casual-hipster-indifferent.

Chef Kyo is proud of her Nyonya heritage, and it shows in her lovingly composed (and delicious!) food and passion when she talks about it. Walking into her shop for the first time was like walking into an old friend's place where you catch up over Teh Tarik and swap stories about where the best food around is. (Hint: it's right there). Try the nasi lemak (coconut rice) -- fragrant, accompanied with lovely spicy anchovy sambal. Finish with a peanut muachi, warm and and lightly sweet. The weekly coffee shipment from Malaysia (so the beans are fresh) was unfortunately held up, so I'll have to come back for that the next time I'm there.
No comment

Checked out this place on a whim while getting tattooed at First Class Tattoo across the street and was totally blown away by the food and drinks. I HIGHLY recommend the white coffee and the pulut inti (blue sticky rice with shredded coconut). They were suggested to me by their friendly staff and I loved both. Prices are also wonderfully low considering how delicious everything is. Would highly recommend checking them out.

Very happy that this re-opened even closer to home. The LES has been hitting all the right notes. The food is solid - love all the noodles, Kaya toast, desserts, and the best nasi lemak that I've had in a while. Get anything that features pandan. It's such a subtle flavor unique to SE Asia. Btw - I love any restaurant that could bring funky anchovies into the spotlight. Seemed like it was just yesterday that we were the weirdos for eating that sorta stuff. Great for take-out too!

This was a long anticipated place to visit. I went to the old location 2x during the summer and it was closed for construction. Well I finally made it there recently.  And I can say the food was ok. Not great. Expecting most of the food was at least warmed but nope it was cold on a freezing winter day. Taste-wise I won't be coming back.

I was a totally uncultured tourist and ordered the blue rice dessert that I saw on my friend's social media post. There's actually two different ones, and I still don't know what the actual Malaysian names of them are. The person taking my order didn't make fun of me for that, which I really appreciated. I ordered one of each and enjoyed the toasted coconut topping one. The jam topping just wasn't my preference, but the rest of my group really enjoyed it. I'm so glad I got to try them both and am definitely interested in going back to try other desserts. The place is very small though, so try to go during off hours if you want a seat.
No comment
Good for snack and breakfast. The Kaya toast is delicious.

This place is just Awesome. although its not suitable to dine in. (its a tiny lil store with five chairs only) but wont affect the visit. We order the Bone Meat Soup it comes with oily rice, Nasi Lemak and Panggang (Spicy Shirmp + Sticky Rice wrap in Banana Leaf).. If you are into malaysian food. Please visit this place !!!!

Just discovered this little hidden gem. Boy am i happy i came here. The white pulled coffee is amazing!!! I am in love.i bought one finished it and got another one..YES..... I will be coming back here on my days off. Its a small place run by two very sweet women. The food looked delicious and i will be coming back to try it soon...
100% Legit. Nasi Lemak brings you home right away. All the kuihs are to die for. You can't go wrong with this place.
My little Malaysian gem. Kyo,  you are fabulous. Your Nasi Lemak is a little reminder of my market in Air Panas, Setapak. Love it!
No comment
A great place to have a "Traditional Nasi Lemak". Desserts are great. Their Teh tarik is awesome.  Highly recommend this place.

Kueh lapis in NYC? No way!! Craving for a taste of home, I made a special trip to Chinatown for my fix. The kueh lapis and teh tarik were decent, though not quite as delicious as that from Bengawan Solo and Ya Kun in Singapore. But beggars can't be choosers- I'm not spending three hours laboriously baking kueh lapis layer by layer. A return to Kopitiam will certainly be on the cards, and I can't wait to try their other kuehs (sticky steamed cakes) and reputedly silky smooth kaya (pandan custard jam).

A cozy little place with a chill ambiance and delicious food. We had one of the tables without the benches, and extremely uncomfortable triangular small stools. However, we managed. We had a variety of things - the pandan butter toast, the nasi lemak, the shroom, spicy cold sesame noodles, and a couple of dessert items. Everything was great but the shroom really stood out - the most flavorful mushrooms with red chillies, coconut, onions and curry leaves. It was very spicy but the coconut rice complemented it really well. I'd go again just for that. Overall, the portions run on the small side but that isn't a problem because you can try multiple things.

SO HAPPY I FOUND THIS!  After going to Malaysia and Singapore a few months back, I've been craving kaya toast, and I was soooo excited when I found that this place has it that I went out of my way just to get it. I wasn't disappointed at all - the food was really authentic!  They gave a generous amount of kaya as well!  Spot isn't ideal for dining there, but that's completely fine because the taste, quality and price of the food all make up for it.

Love this place!!!! Their Nasi lemak is my favorite savory dish. Plenty of anchovies sand great flavor combo. Their sweets are all pretty good. Their mochi is memorable because it is  unbelievably soft. Their pandas toast is also great!!
So far I've tried the cold sesame noodles and blue sticky rice with coconut....both excellent! Love this little spot. The service is very friendly too, which is another reason I will be back!
A hidden gem!  The hand pulled coffee is strong and delicious - unlike any coffee I have had in the city (less acidic than most).  Their butter toast is also a great, unique breakfast!
Great food! But left smell on my clothing and bookbag  but food was awesome so was the service. I believe they moved . This review is in reference to previous location

Love this hole in the wall find! Authentic Malaysian desserts and savory dishes. I tried the spicy anchovies with peanuts on coconut rice and white coffee - both was delicious! The spicy anchovies was salty and flavorful pairing nicely with the rice. The white coffee was different than anything I've ever tried. I'll definitely be back to try other desserts and of course, another cup of white coffee.

Paid a visit to the new store, i think staff are newly hired and seemed clueless, especially the bartender and cashier, more improvement needed. I ordered teh tarik, very very diluted and tasteless, could use more condensed milk. Nasi lemak and kaya butter toast is nice!
No comment

You know a restaurant is not that good when they can mess up something so simple as a cup of coffee. My best friend is Malaysian and I know Malaysian coffee. I couldn't read the menu the letter wings are so small that I asked them to recommend a nice ice coffee light and sweet. Terrible $5 in the garbage
No comment
White coffee - bean roasted in butter and mixed with condensed milk, def addicting for those that likes coffee creamy with sugar.

For sure, it's the first time and the last time.  I passed by and see the crowd and guessed the food must be good.  Ordered three dishes Hainaese chicken rice and Fish ball soup with vermicelli noodle then Keya butter toast. The Hainaese chicken looks more like a turkey leg then a chicken leg.  The chicken tasted very  bland and tuff and not to mention the round ball rice.  The rice balls were cold so were the chicken legs.  The dish should rename Cold Hainaese Chicken and Round Ball Rice, so the customer won't get confuse the original Haine Chicken dish.  The fish ball soup is not worth it. The portion are very small, so I ordered Keya butter toast, it's so sweet.  The portion of the dishes are small and over price.  I was going order more dishes,but after tried three dishes, we decided not to take any more chance.  One lesson that I learned don't trust the crowd and reviews that I read. The two stars is for the service.

I came here as I was getting off the train and saw this tiny shop. They only have a few things on the menu and it was very straightforward. Coffee, entrees, snacks. I opted for the nasi lemak because I always get that when I go have Malaysian food. The wait took a while because there was quite a bit of people but it wasn't too long. I took it to go to bring home. It was a ball of rice covered with anchovies marinated in a spicy chili sauce with a hard boiled egg on the side. It was very delicious and for $5.50, it was very fair. The rice and the fish combination was a good balance. A little spicy and the rice was coconut flavored. I will come back to try other things or maybe just get the nasi lemak over and over again.
Brings something unique for coffee drinkers. Especially in a city with too many options.

This brings a whole meaning to "don't judge a book by its cover". Food and staff is truly wonderful! It's such a small cute store, I would think most people would just walk pass it. I saw a crowd inside and it got me curious to sample some of their food. They have both sweet and savory items and it didn't disappoint! In fact, it actually surprised me because I've never had this type of flavor before..pretty much retaught my taste palette again here. I've had food in Malaysian restaurant but nothing like this. They have items that is not available in any other places but here. They also have their own version of tea or they call it as "teh tarik / pulled tea" which is very aromatic. Try it out if you're in the neighborhood. 5 stars for sure anytime.

My first time eating Malaysian food and I chose the best. I live in the neighborhood and have wanted to try this place for some time. I met Mark when I walked in. He was super helpful. Explained the menu to me. I ordered Nazi Lemak and White coffee. The food came quickly.  One of the owners, Moonlynn, heard me say that I had never had Malaysian food before so she brought me a serving of kaya toast. So scrumptious!  I look forward to eating here again. Food, service, and friendliness of the people who work there were all 5 stars. I highly recommend Kopitiam.
Finally good Malaysian food in NYC! Delicious drinks, yummy food, and a very cute atmosphere. This is definitely somewhere I will return again and again

A cute spot with a limited seating. I've only had their Kaya Butter Toast and I'm a sucker for it. It's $3 for two slices of toast with Kaya spread and butter but... I just can't turn away from it. It's sweet and very coconut-y. And oh, great service too.

This is the cutest place ever. Very photogenic and calm environment. My mother and I are from Arizona and are visiting. We walked all the way from Tompkins square park to the Brooklyn bridge and I forced her to go in. So thankful I did! I really highly recommend the white iced coffee
Hole in the wall but really good Kaya! Or I guess the only place that sells kaya in town. (Correct me if I'm wrong 'cause I've been looking for kaya for a long time)
Owner/chef is so sweet!  And food is to die for.   But the sweet (my personal preference) as well as the savory.  Run, don't walk.
This is why we live in New York.  Novel, fresh and rare.  Never experienced this cuisine or presentation before. Well worth a stop for a hand pulled tea and daily delight
No comment
I anticipated this to be better, but I don't know if I will be returning because the food looked better than it tasted. It's a very small shop. Very quiet and oddly awkward.

Great chili in the Nasi Lemak. Very authentic tiny cafe. We ordered the spicy noodles, eggs, Teh Tarik, and Kay's toast. Nothing disappointed. The place could definitely do with more seating, however. We will be back!

Have to go back as the mochi here, alone, is amazing. Best I've had in NYC yet. Have to go back to try the coffee, something I quite enjoy myself, but having coffee that sounds so appealing, even my non coffee drinking girlfriend wants to try.

I just came in for a cup of coffee ($4!) and it was gross! There was no flavor, it was like a cup of hot water. There was a group ahead of me and I think they were just rushing to get orders done and seeped all the coffee grounds together which made the coffee flavorless. Maybe next time I'll go in for food because it smelled great and the servers were super nice.
The whole menu is very interesting, I tried the crabcake and milk tea which tasted delicious!!! Definitely will return again!

The best place!! If you want Malaysian food don't even bother running around in the city. This is the place!  Wish she has several locations so I don't have to come all the way down to canal but until then I will. It is well worth it. Their food is real as it can be. To keep her food so close to what original Malaysian food should taste like she doesn't even replace her ingredients but directly imported from Malaysia to make this happen. What a passion! Everything I tried so far is just phenomenal! Wish I took some photos so I can upload. Maybe I will do that next time and write another review! I can't wait to go again! I so recommend this place. So worth it. :)
Really small place with a small menu but the Pulut and hand pulled tea were delicious.
this cafe is adorable and the food is all so solid!! the staff is generally pretty friendly and they have such a great vibe going on! good coffee, lots of snack options.
Very traditional nyonya food which it's almost impossible to find it in NYC. Very nice! Nomnomnom

Came in with a friend today and the server was very friendly. The place is very small, but we managed to get seats. The nasi lemak is a MUST! The chilled spicy sesame noodles was okay. Quick service and good food. Definitely a place to check out!
Yummy food, reasonable price and friendly staffs, the most delicious Malaysian food I have ever had!
Small space but staff are super friendly and everything I've had so far is delicious.

Great little gem only two blocks away! The fiancé's family is from Malaysia so I knew we had to give it a try and it did not disappoint. We both had the nasi lemak, white coffee for me, and hand pulled tea for him. The owner hand pulls the coffee and tea in a traditional Malaysian style. Everything is made fresh daily by her as well! The sambal sauce was so yummy I had to buy a jar to bring home. I'm already planning to go back later tonight to pick up some sweets and possibly another cup of coffee!

I have been coming back consistently since I've found this little gem.  My friend and I come here often just for the Malaysian ice tea which is beyond refreshing.  We also came for take out.  I had the Nasi Lemak and my friend had the Pulut Panggang.  Both were absolutely delicious but I absolutely love mine.  Apparently everyone love it too because whenever I step into this place, someone is eating Nasi Lemak.

Simple, small place with amazing food!     You feel the love and care going into each dish ...what I imagine the best Malaysian mom's cooking would taste like: simple and homey and delicious and comforting.   I can eat here every day.
I think this place is precious!  I tried five different items from the menu.  They were all excellent! My new fav place!

Love this place! Tasty, unusual food. Yelp prices out of date but it's still reasonably priced. Loved the crazy french toast and every savory thing I've tried. Loud music, but really there are only a few stools, so I get my food to go.

This place is dope. I don't say that because the food is so phenomenal that it deserves 5 stars alone, but rather that Kopitiam fills a distinct vacuum in the Manhattan gastronomic world, where Asian food is common but authentic Malaysian food is rare. You've got Chinatown already, which while ridiculously disappointing still has some decent restaurants popping up here and there. There isn't necessarily a wide variety of Vietnamese restaurants, but there are plenty to also be found in Chinatown. Thai food is scattered aplenty throughout the city. Indian food's got its hubs as well. Filipino food has firmly entrenched itself with Maharlika and Jeepney, but Malaysian food's only got Nyonya, and even then Nyonya has gotten so bad in recent years that it's not even worth going to. Enter Kopitiam, a pop-up shop in the truest since of the word that has seating for 4 people max located on the fringe of Chinatown. Reasonably priced along with a fairly diverse menu, a trip here will almost always hit the spot. The staff is incredibly friendly and welcoming as well. I'd personally recommend the crab ball, butter toast (oh so divine) and the stick rice with shrimp floss are all good. I've tried the Nasi Lemak and I've come to the conclusion that I'm more turned off by the dish itself than by Kopitiam's iteration. I've been to Chomp Chomp, a Singaporean restaurant in west village that also serves the famed Malaysian dish but have found it to be pretty disappointing. The sesame noodles here are decent but it tends to be overly salty and oily. If you're really hankering for something filling I would recommend the french toast with condensed milk (a note here that condensed milk is to SE Asian dessert food as mayo is to Paula Deen's cook book). Oh and I'd ask for off-menu items when you get there. On one particular evening, we were served a mint egg drop soup that hit the spot. Overall, I'd highly recommend Kopitiam as an introduction to Malaysian food. For the time being it's very cheap and very accessible.

The pulut panggang and white coffee were exceptional in its taste. Days after eating the Malaysian tamale, I fantasized about the glutinous rice tamale with shrimp floss and the spicy sauce that accompanied it.  So far the only items I tried, but I will definitely be back. In short- Modest little place, items very reasonably priced, good vibes.

The chef recommended the oyster omelet and it was delicious!!!!!!! That is my new favorite, along with the nasi lemak, kaya toast... and everything else on the menu. This is an inexpensive, authentic hole in the wall.  I always make sure to visit when I'm in the neighborhood.

I'm no expert on Malaysian culture or cuisine but this small hole in the wall (only counter space with several stools) fits the need for small snacks and Malaysian tea/coffee. The man who served me politely explained their most popular coffee offering, the traditional Penang white coffee (made with margarine and condensed milk I think). The coffee itself tasted a little bit like a cafe con leche with a slight roasted after taste. When I'm in the area next time, I may try some of their food offerings.

I love kaya toast! In Thailand it's everywhere so when in NYC I had to try it. The place is Malaysian and super delicious. I got a cup of hand pulled tea with my toast, it was cool watching her shift the tea from one cup to the other.
The best white coffee in town. Friendly staff and great food . It's a must try place!!

The soft boiled eggs were ready in no time at all. But that's probably because they had been sitting there for a while: because they were cold. The pulled tea was excellent and they accommodated my special order of one that's less sweet, made with evaporated and an added teaspoon of condensed milk for just a tinge of sweetness.

This place is good - not great and not bad. The best thing there was the teh tahrik (hand pulled tea). We ordered the nasi lemak and even though the dish is traditionally pretty simple - the flavors to this dish were very mediocre . We also ordered soft boiled eggs and sticky rice with dried shrimp flakes - which were made well. This place is good for a snack but don't expect to leave here super satisfied.
I'm glad we went out of the way to try this delicious white coffee. I definitely recommend it.

This place is AUTHENTIC! My family and I were in NYC over the summer and chanced upon Kopitiam. It was so good we came back another day for more... We're from Singapore and the food here is just like at home. The Nasi Lemak was really fantastic - full flavored coconut rice, and the sambal ikan bills (chili fish sauce) had a real kick in both flavour and heat. Also had the pulut panggang and that was great too. If you want something sweet - try the sticky rice deserts - they're all good. If you are from Malaysia and Singapore, you'd love this place. If you want an authentic taste of Malaysia and Singapore, this is it!
white coffee was great, kaya toast and boiled eggs were the bomb and super cheap.

I think this is probably a bit of an acquired taste.  The flavors are different and interesting, but not something I crave.  The kaya jam is amazing and should be put on everything - the toast or the morning glory (blue rice).  I had the morning glory with coconut and while it was good, I think it would have been better with kaya jam.  The nasi lemak reminded me of Isan thai food - strong fish flavor and spicy - something that's nice every once in a while.  The white coffee I know a lot of other people loved, but it tasted like instant coffee to me.  The place is tiny with probably 6 seats of which a third are behind the counter for the employees.  They are helpful and friendly and take credit card, what else could you want from such a tiny place?

The owner were  incredibly nice. I'm not sure how any of you can take pictures then eat. I got home and the food were GONE! Heck with the pictures! The food were incredible, I've never had this type of Malaysian food. The owner told me these were recipes from Grandparents. Sweets were really good too and not too sweet. The white coffee was also pretty good. Will definitely be back for more! Try it you won't regret.

Sounds great, looks tempting, taste amazing! Went to this place for the first time and was stunned by the visual and color of the food and moreover, taste of the food. The two ladies working there are nice and warm, and very professional. Definitely a return and recommend for this place!!

Need more places like this in NYC. The owner/chef makes everything from scratch in her little kitchen. She makes what she would eat at home. White Coffee is a must. I had the nasi lemak. Perfect snack portion, maybe more than a snack portion, depending on your appetite. The rice was cooked perfectly and topped with the salty dried fish in a very aromatic spicy paste. It can be a bit fishy for people who are not used to heavy spice. I really enjoyed the dish. Also got the blue sticky rice with shredded coconut steamed in pandan leaves. After my meal, I got another dish to go because I saw another guest ordered it. I can't remember the name, but it's sticky rice steamed in pandan leaves, filled with shredded shrimp. Definitely recommend all three dishes I ordered.

An absolute gem. The food, both savory and sweet, is amazing. We had the butter toast (then ordered it again because it was so good), the cold spicy sesame noodles which were amazing and the nasi lemak, which was flavorful but not for those who don't like a very fishy flavor. The white coffee was also great. He staff are also incredibly sweet and make this such a great place to visit. I couldn't recommend this more.

In this lonely city of New York, all I want is some comfort and coffee on point. I found both at Kopitiam. It's a cozy restaurant run by a lovely couple, Kyo and Nan. Kyo told me that the menu was inspired by her childhood memories in Malaysia...the food she ate as a kid in the street and at home. All of her nostalgia is fully present in her food, and it feels so good in my stomach. I had been looking forward to Kopitiam's opening since I tasted their treats at the Queen's night market. When I finally got to visiting the store, she recommended Nasi Lemak, a rice bowl with stir fried anchovies, peanuts, and hard boiled egg. It may sound a bit too ethnic for those not acquainted with anchovies, but once you taste it, you would be surprised at how that spoon continues to shove back in to that bowl. The taste brings back everything: taste from childhood, the memories of my asian background, and the smell of rice from home. The final fulfillment came with the coffee that Nan delicately prepared. It was delicate, potent, yet without acidity...All in all, it just defined and made my saturday morning. Thank you and looking forward to seeing you lovely ladies again!
heard it long time, finally gave a try, rendang ok, nasi lemak ok, but everything too salty n the worst otak i ever tried. bye
friendly and warm hole in the wall.  was in the area and wanted to try the coffee.  pretty expensive for a cup of coffee but it was good.  would definitely come again to try the food next time.

One of the best tacos I have ever had. They are a little pricey compared to what I'm used to- almost $5 a taco. But given the location and the amount of meat they give, plus the amazing flavors, I'd say it's well worth it. I got the adobada and carne asada. The marinate on the adobada was delicious and was my favorite. They also offer unlimited lime and have a salsa station.

Delicious tacos! My favorite was the steak and pork tacos. The chicken was the spiciest of the three. There was a line but it moved quickly.

Dude, this place was so good. It was late in the evening and we were starving, but this place was so good we went back again the next day. Their quesadillas are fantastic.

I went there around 9 30pm today,  it was a little hard to find a table. I ordered 1 quesdilla and 1 taco, flour tortilla was too thin that it ripped easily. Meat flavor was ok nothing special. They had a salsa bar including lime and radish. I think they should put less meat and make it a little cheaper. I felt it was very expensive.. (even horchata was too small here and over priced. lol)

If I could give Tacos No. 1 more than 5 stars I would. I can't even begin to explain how delicious the tacos were! Omg! We had to try everything and I'm so happy we did. The quesadillas and mulas were *chef's kiss - as were the tacos. The asada was juicy, the adobada was perfectly seasoned and tender, the chicken was to die for and the nopal was a great surprise since I rarely see it on menus. I know adobada as Al pastor - just wanted to put that out there in case you know it like I do. The horchata was classic and made perfectly. The Jamaica is just how my mom makes it. The service is fast and friendly, the music and atmosphere definitely take this place to the next level. I'd travel to NY just go have these tacos again. They were that good.

I've always wanted to try this spot since I heard so many great things! I got here on a weekday afternoon, but there is a crazy crowd with the line out the door. The place is very tiny, with no seating space, just standing eating stations. There were sauces and condiments on the side that you can grab yourself. I ordered al pastor, which is my go to taco anywhere. I thought they were good tacos, flavorful, but not the oomph I was hoping for because of all the raving reviews. But still good.

Chelsea Market has these tacos and they are as close as this CA native can get in NY. It was a fast and efficient process from the line formation to the collection of your purchased tacos. They have horchata which makes any Mexican place legit in my opinion. All in all, definitely recommend the asada with everything on.

Truly the best taco I've had in my life. There was a fast moving line but the tacos made every minute worth it. The tacos were packed with flavor in each bite- the pork on flour was absolutely amazing. It was an awesome experience watching the food get made and being immersed in the ambiance.

I've been meaning to try these for the longest and they were delicious. Although they are pricey for the size, I still had no regrets. It's basically $4 for a taco that you take two bites of. Being from California and a regular visitor to Tijuana, B.C. I had to see if NY was truly getting authentic MX tacos. They definitely brought the West Coast taco scene to the East Coast. Even when standing in line, the menu and font style as well as the decor is similar to taqueria's in LA and in Baja California. The service was decent considering how long the line was when I arrived. Now for the food. I got 2 tacos (1 carne asada & 1 adobada) for $13 after taxes. If the prices were closer to the cost of tacos in LA or Tijuana, I think I could give 5 stars. Overall, this is indeed the spot I would recommend for anyone visiting NY and wants tacos. There are other menu items but I literally did not see anyone ordering anything else. Salud!

Good place for tacos by the theaters. If you're looking for something quick to eat before a show this could be it. I had the carne asada tacos. The meat was tasty and it came with guacamole. I also got the chips & guac. It seemed pretty authentic. I'd recommend a stop by here.

By far the best tacos I have ever had!   A MUST go to when you are in NYC.   High quality meets and tortillas.  Quick and filling.   Learned from a New Yorker to order the quesadilla as it is the most bang for you buck and there is cheese added to it.  Every time I go to NYC I will be checking in here.

Delicious tacos both the carnitas and chicken flavor. Quick and casual service. It's not a place to dine in since you have to stand but worth the trip.

We came on in the evening and the line wasn't too bad, and it went fast. I got two tacos (the chicken and pork one) and a horchata. Everything was good! Service is super fast, they give you a ticket and basically make your taco immediately.

The place is packed for a reason!! The meat was well seasoned and the portions were great! Very traditional and worth every penny . The jugo de jamaica was amazing ! And the tacos u can't go wrong with any of them, full of flavor . My best recommendation... get three lol because one will leave u wanting more !!

This place is a madhouse all times of day. There is a lot of attention to detail with the staff making sure everything is clean and the bottles of soda have plenty of ice. I love the service and the operation they run. There is a simple menu but they execute on every one of them. Behind the counter they have a huge pork skewer roasting over a spit. I ordered the mula which is a meat between 2 tortilla's. Kind of like a sandwich. The tacos are delicious too with the homemade tortilla's tying everything together. Loved the al pastor and steak. No eating at the counter if you are waiting for your food. I made that mistake! The food is delicious and I would come back in a heartbeat. Tacos are the stars but anything on the menu works.
This place has a short menu, and no seating. Come here just for the tacos. I always get the carne asada tacos with everything on them and they are amazing every time.

Lowkey taco stand slinging out amazing food!!!!!! 2 is more than filling but wanted to try all 3 ... the adobada was my favorite by far but all of em were incredible. Line forms pretty quickly but moves fast and is well worth the wait. Best taco in NYC!!!!

Busy than busy but they move you through as quick as they can. Tacos were definitely craveable. You can standup at their table but not a place you hang around for long, it's just quick once you get your order. Total time- line (20+ minutes) food from order to mouth (less than 5!)

This is one of my favorite places to grab a bite before a show. The line may look long, but it moves pretty fast! I like to get 2-4 tacos depending on how hungry I am, or replace one with a quesadilla if I am really craving cheese. Occasionally I treat myself to a Coke. I would avoid the steak as I find it kind of bland- the Carne Asada is very well-spiced and is definitely my favorite. The chicken is also decent.

Best taco I have ever had.  Carved asada and pork. Really good. I have nothing more to say, but need to type more.

Amazing and authentic! I live in San Diego, California and we have pretty good Mexican food. Los Tacos No. 1 made me feel right at home! These are fresh and amazing tacos. I recommend the Adobada tacos with everything on them "con todo". You will not be disappointed.
